reviewText:
HatredDeveloper: Destructive Creations
Publisher: Destructive Creations

Note: A key for this game was provided by the developer for the purpose of writing an unbiased informative review. No other compensation was given.

Introduction
==========
Hatred certainly got some attention back when it was first revealed on Steam. A lone man decides he wants to kill as many innocent people as possible in any way he can because he is sick and tired of humanity. Oh yeah, I can see how it got a little...controversial. Let's keep in mind that it's just a GAME and take a closer look at it.

Gameplay
==========
At it's core, Hatred is a twin-stick shooter. Your left stick moves the Antagonist (let's just call him Guy), and the right stick aim's Guy's weaponry. Guy can carry many different guns and 3 different grenades. It's your mission to use these tools as best you can and kill anything that moves. Simple, but the controls are a bit challening to master. Aiming can sometimes a pose a challenge as well. Once innocents hear gunshots, they start panicing and running away, presenting you with constantly moving targets. If you get their health down low enough to where they are suffering, you can perform an execution, which sometimes zooms in onto Guy and shows you in great detail how he kills this person. Sometimes it's by slitting their throat, or by shooting them in the forehead. Either way, it's extremly graphic, and some people might find them a bit disturbing. Performing an execution is literally the only way to regain lost health, so try to do these finishers when you are running low.

Guy can also hijack cars off the street and drive them around. Again, the controls for the game make this a challenge, but it's useful for getting to your different objectives. Speaking of objectives, these include crashing parties, or mowing down an entire police station full of cops. Clearing these objectives unlocks that location as a respawn point. When you finally die, you are able to respawn at that location, but beware! You have a limited number of respawns until the game is over completely.

Each map is pretty large and full of people to kill. You can freely enter any homes or buildings you stumble across, and kill anyone inside. If the doors are locked, you can kick them down. Lots of houses have explosive containers inside, which explode violently when shot. This is pretty helpful in clearing rooms indoors, especially at parties! The most annoying thing about this game is as you kill more and more people, police will start to swarm to your location and try to take you down, very similarly to GTA. At first they are very manageable and easy to kill, but as more show up you can quickly find yourself overwhelmed.

There are 2 playable modes: Story Mode, and Survival Mode. They are both exactly what they sound like. On the main menu you get to choose between the two, as well as if you want to take a short tutorial first (this is recommended).

Graphics
==========
The entire game is a mix of black and white hues, with only blood to offset things. Blood is plentiful as you kill people, so you will be seeing a lot of it. It even splashes up onto the screen. While the overall effect is really nice, it gets just a tad old to look at after a few hours. Explosions look really nice, especially when you get a few people caught in it, with the resulting splash of blood painting the surroundings in thick crimson hues.

The opening cutscene is well done, and looks very detailed, but it shares the same black and white tones as the rest of the game. It's a nice theme for the game, as it is very dark and violent, so it makes sense.

Sound and Music
==========
The music is pretty standard, but what shines here are the sound effects and voice overs. Gunshots and bodies hitting the ground sound great (can't believe I just said that o.O), and he majority of the time you are going to hear police sirens and people screaming for their lives as they run in terror.

Lots of obscenities are heard as people flee, as well as the sound of their blood splashing onto the ground as they are gunned down. Nice touches, although a bit morbid. It fits the game's theme pretty well though.

Performance
==========
Hatred runs surprisingly well, although sometimes loading takes a bit. It's very obvious when you first boot up the game, as the game doesn't even show up after hitting Play until at least 2 minutes later, whereas most games boot up instantly or after a few seconds. I got 60 FPS at all times, and experienced no crashes, stuttering, or framerate drops...even when causing massive explosions resulting in showers of blood.

The game played very well with my Logitech F310 controller. I didn't even try the keyboard. The controls take a little getting used to, but once you get it it's not a big issue and actually compliment the game pretty well.

Final Thoughts
==========
Decent as a game, even if the concept is a bit questionable. Good for several hours of fun mowing down 'enemies'. It's not a very deep or complex game...Just don't take it seriously and you'll find some enjoyment in it as you play. It can be pretty difficult as you go along, but it's worth giving a try just to see what all the fuss was about.

Gameplay Demo
==========
https://youtu.be/QhkGffW4ny0

Nerd House Verdict:
==========
Recommended

Be sure to check out Nerd House Gaming for more reviews!

reviewText:
Hatred is basically a modern version of the original Postal. It's incredibly violent, gory, and contains the worse bad language i've seen, or rather heard, in any game to date. It certainly warrants it's adult rating and isn't something you'd want your kids to play.
You play as a guy who's gone 'Postal' going through each level dealing death and destruction with a variety of weapons. There's a few side missions you can do on the way such as chasing down a politician, derailing a train and wiping out a coffee shop full of 'hipsters'. It plays pretty well, though i recommend keyboard and mouse as i found using a controller just isn't accurate enough. Visually it's very nice, it's well animated with some nicely detailed backdrops and some really great fire and explosion effects. The sound is also good, with a moody soundtrack that's not too distracting and some meaty gunfire and explosions. There's also some nice little touches like clips from Rambo and Matrix played on tv screens throughout and the credits gave me a laugh.

What i did like is the challenge. Early on it's fairly easy with just Cops to deal with but the latter stages, when the Army turn up, are a real challenge. Infact the last two levels took me multiple tries and that was on 'easy' difficulty! It requires a little planning ahead as running in guns blazing will get you killed in no time.
My only real complaint is that because of the isometric viewpoint it's fairly easy to get stuck behind walls, trees, fences and the like, but it's something you get used to after a while.

All in all i enjoyed it. And if you're a fan of Postal or infact any top down shooter i'm sure you'd enjoy Hatred. Especially as it's so challenging.

I recommend it.

reviewText:
This game is basically the first Postal but remade with modern graphics: Same isometric perspective, same concept of a disturbed person deciding he's going to kill everyone, same core gameplay of shooting everything and everyone in mini-sandbox levels, and even similar black comedy one-liners whenever the protagonist kills someone. Hell, it even starts identically with the protagonist standing outside his house before you open fire on civilians. From there you run around an open map going to marked locations (killing civilians and cops/SWAT along the way) such as shops/malls/hotels/bars/etc., kill more NPCs then go somewhere for the level to end. Afterwards, you do the same thing in a different level. If you find a car with its doors open you can hijack it and drive around running over people, but they're a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ to control and not worth the bother outside the hilarity factor of crashing them through walls - that's another good thing, there's plenty of destructible environments in the game, with walls and furniture falling apart and crumbling completely if explosions happen nearby or you crash objects through them.
The biggest problem with the game is the same one most games of its genre have: the isometric perspective makes combat a pain since you don't know exactly where your shots will land or if they will go over certain objects, the black and white colour filter makes it even more disorienting to move around and doesn't help matters.

Since its announcement, there's been a ton of drama surrounding this game due to its concept and some of the developers being affiliated to neo-Nazi Polish groups. Playing it, you'd be hard-pressed to find any overt racism, misogyny or what have you (though there's a snarky Feminist achievement) since you kill all types of people.
If you're buying this just to get back at people who anger you on the internet I'd suggest you reconsider, you're part of the group that the developers are baiting and counting on to buy this game since it's nothing special. But it's your money, so do whatever.

I bought this expecting a game similar to Postal and that's exactly what I got, but in the end I'm not sure if I'd recommend it to anyone unless, of course, you also liked the original Postal. It's a dumb, trashy game that happens to have pretty graphics. Despite being a few hours long you'll have seen everything the gameplay has to offer in less than half hour. Get it when it's u$15 or less during a sale if you're really curious about it.

After playing for a few hours it becomes a chore to play with mind-numbingly tedious, repetitive gameplay and heavy, sluggish controls. A typical late-game experience for me involved this:

reviewText:
Hatred is dull.  Why is that you say?  Because, every aspect of this twin-stick shooter is dull, repetitive, frustratingly difficult at the later levels.  Oh and the game is 4 hours...  Giving how little this game offers, there's absoultely no reason to replay it once the credits starts rolling.  Hatred tries to go for dark/edgy story and it ends up being pointless and very comical.  In fact, the game tries to make the main character feel very important, but given how stereotypical his character is.  He ends up being so unlikable throughout this boring genocidal rampage.  His lines are so cringeworthy that I almost feel sick from hearing it.

The levels are extremly repetitive, as you go out shoot and kill many civiains in order to advance to the next area and do it again.  You do sometimes have different objectives that isn't invold in killing, but getting to one place and then you go kill more people...  That's pretty much what Hatred is.  The game suprisingly have fantastic controls and thats the only good part about this game.  The destruction is also nice, but not as impressive like in Battlefield: Bad Company 2!  The shooting itself is ok and the enemy AI is decent at best.  Not much to say a whole lot thou.

Oh right, Hatred also has the worst checkpoint system ever and it adds nothing but problems to the game.  Those checkpoints gives you continues as you do repetitive side task by doing exact same thing that you do throughout the whole game. (KILLING PEOPLE!!!)  Once you earned it, you better make sure you don't die that often, because this game gets ridiciously hard very late in the game.  If you die you will respawn back to the first checkpoint.  Sadly, the game does a very poor job on this, as you will mostly respawn back to the first place you earned it at or sometimes the respawns can get you killed or worse, getting stuck!  Make one fatal mistake and it will cost you a continue, lose all those continues and its game over and you'll have to start all over at the beginning of the god damn level.

Overall, its a poor game and a waste of value!  There's no multiplayer for that matter and a lack of bonus extras.  I don't know why this got so much attention, its a painfully average game with almost nothing new brought to the table.  Do yourself a favor: go spend your money on The Witcher III, than playing this game!

reviewText:
Not even close to as bad or offensive as the press make it out to be.

It's a noirish, slick, fun tribute to great old school shooters. Especially the Playstation 1 and late 90's era such as Crusader No Remorse, Die Hard Trilogy, Loaded, Postal 1 and newer ones such as Manhunt, Dead Nation and Hotline Miami at the top of my head.

The dialogue and lines of the antagonist is a lovely throwback to 70's, 80's b-movie slasher and horror films that don't take themselves seriously.

Great developers, engine and mod support too!

reviewText:
Hatred has caused quite a few waves within the mainstream media. People have called it everything from a political statement to absolute proof of the degeneration of society. While there were a few cinematic executions that I found pretty cringe-worthy, most of the game is spent too far in the sky to discern much of the destruction happening down in the isometric hellscape that â€œThe Antagonistâ€ is intent on creating. Hatred certainly has its strong points, such as destructible environments. However, it also falls short on basic things like dialogue. Some lines are so cheese-covered that Iâ€™m going to need some nachos before finishing this review. The variety of objectives is lackluster, but if you go into Hatred with the idea that it really is just a brainless isometric shooter, it can easily work its charm on you. Is it worth the massive amount of hype? Letâ€™s take a deeper look at Hatred.

The first thing you will notice as you burst into the streets will probably be the smooth gunplay, followed closely by the fact that AI civilians are extremely stupid. As you fire your assault rifle many will flee, some will cower, and a few will run directly towards the barrel of your weapon. This is a bit of a positive note, since the only way to recover health is to execute the injured, and the police are extremely determined to end your killing spree. As you advance through the game you will take down local cops, SWAT teams, and the army. There are only five weapons and three grenades to pick from unfortunately, and this along with lack of enemy variety hurts the replayability. Iâ€™d love to face down a tank with an RPG, but it never happened. Antagonist, I am disappoint. Hatred does have its fair share of clipping and optimization problems. The plot and execution are far from being innovative. The Antagonist is the antithesis of likeable or believable, but somehow even with its blemishes, underneath is a wonderfully built game.

The monochrome aesthetic is extremely effective here. Red and blue are the only real colors, which keeps Hatred from feeling too real. This might be a negative for some, for me itâ€™s a definite positive. Sounds are extremely realistic, from firing a gun to pleas for mercy. The lines for The Antagonist are cheesy, but delivered well. Thereâ€™s not a lot a voice actor can do with a script like this one. The game is extremely difficult even on normal mode, you get a respawn for completing side-objectives. While these do help a ton, if you die during the levelâ€™s main objective, you will be forced to start the entire level over. I enjoy the level design a whole lot, and if you donâ€™t like something in the level, you can simply blow most of it up! Grenading your way through the side of a building and opening fire on anyone inside is extremely gratifying.

I wonâ€™t attempt to take the supposed moral high-ground, as I play games with a similar amount of violence almost daily. Hotline Miami, Grand Theft Auto, Postalâ€¦ Hell, even the fatalities in Mortal Kombat are far more gory than anything this game offers. If you feel bad about shooting civilians, let the police shoot you without reason (and they will) so you can feel justified. The only reason this game was awarded an AO rating and effectually ostracized from console gamers is simply due to lack of corporate ties, and maybe some marketing that was a bit too good. I donâ€™t hesitate to say that Hatred doesnâ€™t live up to the hype, but that doesnâ€™t make it a bad game by any means. Firefights are a lot of fun, especially when you keep shooting the door jamb and expanding the hole. Overall Hatred is worth a look for anyone who enjoys isometric shooters and a touch of gore. Big thanks to Destructive Creations for the review copy, I hope you guys will continue to get under the skin of the mainstream gaming industry for a long time to come.

Gameplay:

Controls- 6/10
Fun Factor- 8/10
Difficulty- 10/10
Replayability- 6/10
Innovation- 3/10

Aesthetic:

Graphics- 10/10
Music- 7/10
Sound FX- 10/10
Story/Lore- 3/10
Level Design- 8/10

Final Score: 71/100 for aesthetic, difficulty, and edge. So much edge.

Summary: Pretty and brutal isometric shooter, based around â€œThe Antagonistâ€, who decides to create his solution to overpopulation.
Verdict: Destructible environments, well-designed gunplay, and brutal difficulty make this game an above-average pick.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l3A_talaCo8

I suppose a decent place to start would be to address the games supposed shock value. After all the main character is a genocidal maniac bent on murdering hundreds of innocent people, however despite this grisly and sinister concept, Hatred does nothing to make you guilty of the atrocities you find yourself committing. The supposed shock value is simply not present here, while playing Hatred I felt no remorse and no guilt for killing all these innocent people, and that is not because Iâ€™m a horrible person, there are many games which managed to produce an emotional response from myself and many other players, however Hatred is not one of those games. You will care about as much about the civilians in Hatred as those roaming the streets of GTA 5s Los Santos or Saints Rows Steel port. These people have no names, no backstory, no personality. They are nothing but pixels on a computer monitor, and no matter if you kill, 10, 100, 1000 of them, the emotional response will be about the same as if you were instead shooting zombies.

You will not care at all, and more to the point from the moment you start playing, you will find it simply impossible to take Hatred seriously. The games main character is perhaps the most obnoxious and ludicrous antagonist I have ever played in a video game. He doesnâ€™t feel like an introverted and mentally disturbed spree killer, instead he is much more akin to a James Bond villain. That is if a James Bond villain was written by a twelve year old. Indeed his dialogue is so utterly absurd and his constant one-liners so cheesy and ridiculous, that instead of feeling shocked by this guys psyche I found myself bursting into laughter on multiple occasions.

But I digress. Hatred was never intended to be a deep look at the physiology and mental condition of spree killers, and none of what I previously mentioned would at all matter if only Hatred was a fun video game, which it saddens me to say, it is not. At its core, Hatred is a fairly mediocre top down twin stick shooter. Itâ€™s gunplay is unexceptional at best and utterly frustrating at worst. Far too often the clumsy movement combined with the lack of a cover system means that often you will have no idea where youâ€™re being shot from or indeed if you can hit a certain enemy that might or might not be behind a piece of cover. This issue is made even worse by the fact that Hatreds levels have no checkpoints, and should you die you will be forced to restart the entire level. The only way to get around that is to earn so called â€œrespawn tokensâ€ which do exactly what it says on the tin and can be obtained by completing certain side objectives, of which there are about two or three in each level. But perhaps the worst crime committed by Hatred, is being a boring video game.

Some games are short but sweet, others are long and monotonous, however Hatred manages to combine the worst of both worlds, and even if you can pull yourself through the often frustrating combat, even then Hatred will become boring and repetitive long before the credits roll. Most of the levels here work in exactly the same way, the main character arrives in a certain area, after which you have to kill a certain number of people and then proceed to the next level. Rinse and repeat. There is practically zero gameplay variation on offer here and therefore the game gets repetitive extremely quickly. The same goes for the executions, which you will be doing a lot considering they are literally the only way to regenerate your health. Fortunately there is an option to skip the cutscenes which these executions trigger, because just like almost everything else it this game, they get old extremely fast. Any novelty that Hatred might have expires very quickly, which frankly is utterly unforgivable considering that the game itself is not very long at all. It personally took me a mere three hours to complete Hatred, and that is including doing just about all the side objectives in each level, so if you really wanted to rush this thing I could see someone completing the game in around 2 hours, but chances are you will probably get bored before you get there. Destructive Creations wants $20 or Â£15 for this game, and even if it was any good, which it clearly is not, I still highly doubt that many people would want to pay that amount for 2-3 hours of gameplay.

The only redeeming factor here are the games visuals. The almost exclusively black and white colour palette, combined with some nice film grain effects make for an aesthetically pleasing experience. Hatred also utilises Unreal Engine 4 and Nvidiaâ€™s Physics technology to bring a great deal of destructible terrain. Grenades destroy walls and send out flying particles, cars can drive through buildings and bullets tear up walls and architecture. Its truly impressive stuff, unfortunately itâ€™s stuck in the middle of an otherwise un-exiting and outright boring game. But Hatreds problems donâ€™t end there. For one things itâ€™s terribly optimised, and at 1080p I saw the game constantly dropping below 60 frames per second on a very powerful dual GPU setup. The game crashed on me twice, I experienced an array of audio bugs throughout my play trough and the enemy AI is just simply awful. They either blindly rush your position, usually one by one, or simply stand around doing absolutely nothing.

On almost every single level, Hatred is frankly an underwhelming failure of a game. It, rather understandably fails to live up to all the hype that people have built up around it before itâ€™s lunch, it fails to present itself as a piece of meaningful satire and most of all it fails to be an enjoyable  video game. Itâ€™s short, repetitive and looses any sense of novelty within the first hour of playtime. It will not inspire any spree killers and it wonâ€™t turn gamers into sadistic lunatics with a thirst for innocent blood. But you probably already knew that. Instead Hatred commits the greatest crime a video game can commit, at the end of the day, it is simply boring.

reviewText:
UPDATE: In-depth video review is now up, in 2 parts. https://youtu.be/F7lpnZvsONQ

https://youtu.be/rpoxJ47pxCc

I bought the game for the sole purpose of wanting to give it a chance, and probably will do a full video on it later. Despite all the negativity surrounding it, how 'tasteless' it seemed, and by god, the controversy... I just wanted to see how it fared as a game by its own merits.

After playing through it, I can say that it was not worth the money, even if you can get past the awkward, probably disturbing themes to some. But even that wasn't all that disturbing. Death and murder comes so frequently, with so little consequence, reason, or realism that it's barely even worth mentioning.

The Antagonist's dialogue is amazingly terrible, and I'm torn as to whether or not it was done as a parody. Some of the lines are just so stupid that it's hard to imagine it being taken seriously, but.. who knows.

The game runs pretty terribly, usually hovering from 38-45fps on a GTX770, with some settings turned down even. It dipped as low as 20fps in a few parts, and frankly, the game's graphics don't justify it at all. The destruction of the environments was impressive at times, admittedly, but it was usually then that the framerate tanked the hardest.

The game is very short, it took about 3 hours to beat.. probably less if you're not terrible at the game like I was. It's extended through an archaic 'respawn point' system, where you earn a respawn by completing side objectives (kill more people or blow something up, that's about it), and each time you die, you'll spend a point to come back.

If you run out of points, you're put back at the start of the stage. This wouldn't be so bad if the way you recover health was by executing people.. and to do that, you need to shoot someone, or kick someone, enough that they fall down, but aren't quite dead. Then you execute them by pressing 'Q', an animation plays, and you recover some health.

With how difficult the final 2 stages can get, you'll find yourself dying and having to restart repeatedly. It makes the entire thing frustrating, I was just hoping that it would finally be over. Finally being after 2 and a half hours of game time. That's not a good sign.

If you're a fan of gore or excessive violence.. play something else instead.

reviewText:
Hatred is a top down shooter game developed and published by Destructive Creations. The game was famously removed from the Steam Greenlight page due to the extremely violent content, but was later brought back with an apology from Gabe Newell.  The game was fully released in June 2015.

The game got a lot of bad press before its release again due to its supposed highly graphically violent content. There were calls for the game to be banned from Steam and banned from streaming services such as Twitch.tv.  After the release of the game, it turned out that it was not as bad as first though. Whilst the game does have dark tones which could be off putting to some but that is the case with a lot of video games nowadays.

Game play in Hatred is fairly simple. Taking on the characteristics as other top down shooters, where you move around with WASD, shooting and aiming is done with the mouse. The tutorial is fairly informative, and does a good job at easing you into the hair raising gun scenes that you will be heading into. The missions in Hatred all have very clear and simple goals. Kill a certain amount of innocent civilians and also survive against the waves of cops and military personal that will be thrown at you. The early missions are very easy, you only have to kill a small amount of people, and the armed targets which you come up against are just regular cops, but as you progress through the game, you soon start infiltrating fully guarded army bases and nuclear power plants, as you can imagine these are all fairly heavily guarded, and you have to deal with a near constant stream of bad guys. Whilst you have a pretty large health pool, the only way in which you can regenerate your health is by executing someone who is trying to escape you; this replenishes your health to max. There is a good amount of guns to be found in Hatred too; from regular pistols, right up to rocket launchers, you can only carry three weapons at a time though.

Hatred has a very unique looking graphical style. The majority of the game is in black and white, with the odd inclusion of colour every now and again. This does make the game not look as graphically pleasing as others, but it still has a very interesting style which I enjoyed very much.  It fits the mood of the game perfectly. The gameâ€™s main character is voice acted in the cut scenes in between missions, as well as the odd snippet of dialogue in game too, and these are done at a mediocre standard, they are certainly not the best, but by all means, not the worst. It is definitely better than not having any voice acting at all.

This is a hard game, I struggled even on medium difficulty settings, and the later levels of the story mode are insanely difficulty to progress at times, just because of the sheer amount of enemies that get thrown at you at any moment. As soon as you clear one squad of cops, they send in another four or five as backup. You either have to be very quick at dealing with them, or have a good hit and run technique. The only way I found it possible to pass some stages, was to simply spam grenades, the deal catastrophic amounts of damage and am really fun to use.

Each of the gameâ€™s levels are very large, not only do you have the main objective of slaughtering countless civilians and escaping, but the levels also include a minimum of three side objectives for you to complete, these can range from simply killing a politician during a rally, or maybe burning down some shops on the high street. These add a little something extra that takes you away from the sometimes repetitive job of the mindless killing.

Hatred is fairly short game, with only 7 levels I was slightly let down with the amount of content in the story mode. I managed to complete the game in just over two hours.  There is a survival mode which may end up being your cup of tea, but for me this just smells of repetitiveness after five minutes of playing. I would have liked to have seen at least another 7 levels out of the story mode.

I had no major technical problems whilst playing. I did notice a slight stutter to game play when the screen is full of cops and army men shooting at you from all around - my frame rate did drop below 50 fps which was a little annoying, but was able to overlook since I was more focused on not dying. The game does feel a little wonky to control to begin with, but you soon get used to the controls.

To sum up, whilst Hatred definitely did not deserve all of the bad press it got prior to its release; the game does have a dark side to it, but no more than say the likes of GTA which is critically acclaimed. The game play is of a high standard which I thoroughly enjoyed â€“ however the game is let down mostly due to the shortness and lack of content to play. The price of Â£14, 99 is a bit much for a game which I finished in two hours, so this is definitely going to be a game to pick up when it is on sale for less than Â£7.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
This Review was done with a key obtained from the developer.

Summary:
This was a hard choice. Hatred definitely has some appealing elements to it in its great visuals, working with a reasonable art style and a good base engine at the core. The gameplay is where things start to falter. While you do have several objectives every mission to complete with a little bit of variety, it comes down to shooting dudes, and shooting more dudes. Now while that's what is expected in a top down shooter, the lack of variety in that is what is a huge problem over the long run, as a lack of enemy and weapon variety hurts the games overall execution.

Several game design mechanics work against each other, as in particular the execution system being the only way to gain health does not work with the more high action elements of the game. I love the destruction system however. The final two levels difficulty level is through the roof even on the easiest of difficulties, mostly because of the level design themselves: where the game wants you to play long range when you don't have any good long range options. The controversy of the game is overblown as there is most definitely worse games out there in terms of content, although I will say the audio clips did get to me every so often.

In the end, this game is a tough one. It has strengths, there's no doubt about that, but it's the lack of gameplay variety that ultimately gives the game the game a 5.5/10 for me, which makes it an average game. I'd do a thumbs to the side if I could, but when it comes down to it, I put gameplay as my strongest criteria, and for that I have to not recommend the game: but consider it's strengths and what you're looking from the game in question.

Video Review and Gameplay Footage: https://youtu.be/mbkyD4IMH3M

Positives/Negatives
+:
Very good art direction. The choice use of color to draw attention to elements in the environment does extremely well.
Graphics are impressive and the use of the Unreal Engine 4 shows promise for games in the future, even when it's in a grayscale setting for most of it. Details on buildings in particular are rather nice.
Love the destruction feature. I'm a sucker for a good destruction feature, but the fact of the matter is, this one has levels of detail, like being able to shoot a specific hole through a wall, that I haven't seen before. I want to see more of this in future iterations of games.
Some of the side objectives did add some much needed variety, and several of the first set of levels did do a great job in keeping with the needed open type of levels you need in this game.
Most of the time, the performance ran fine for me. While it's not boasting the best FPS, it was passable.-:
Gameplay when it comes down to it lacks major variety. A limited amount of guns and enemy types hurts the game and makes it feel stale rather quickly, which is a major problem.
Enemy AI and civilian AI is dumb. I mean, really dumb. You expect some of it with the nature of the game (it is a target attack after all), but it's taken to a whole new level here, with people running at you, and soliders using rocket launchers on walls. I'm convinced that a pacifism run is possible.
Last two levels in terms of design works against the game's overall game design, and makes a difficulty curve that goes through the roof.
The game's health mechanic works against the game's overall design elements, and really hurts the pace of combat. Same with the respawn tokens, especially WHERE they respawn you. A lot of travelling for no reason.
Some weird camera angles at times, especially when aiming down the sights of your gun.
Game is only 4 hours, and I find that the replayability lacks here with the lack of options.

reviewText:
Hatred is an isometric shooter where you play as a psychopath who's out to murder thousands of people. The premise is simple, but also the very thing that garnered the game so much attention. The game plays well enough, and it's quite violent, but at the same time, I feel the media has made the game out to be worst than it actually is.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ywrJsGtbSdc
Each level of Hatred will provide it's own challenge and goals, many are quite linear, but there are missions where it takes a more open world sandbox approach. As far as gameplay goes, it's your standard issue isometric shooter. You can run, perform executions to replenish your HP, crouch, pick up new weapons, etc, basically, standard fare. One thing Hatred introduces to this genre is the idea of killing innocent NPCs. In other games where the option to kill innocent NPCs are made available, they rarely give the player any incentive to partake in the action, but Hatred doesn't just give incentive, it makes it the main point. The issue with this is, shooting NPCs that can't fight back is really boring! After a while, the police, swat, and military will show up, which makes the game a lot more enjoyable and interesting, but there are some missions where a large portion of it, is rather dull, gunning down hundreds of unarmed NPCs that offer no challenge what so ever.

Artistically the game has it nailed down. It's heavily stylized with it's black and white aesthetics. Pops of red and blue are the only colors that line the game. The lighting and environments look great, brooding and gritty, very appropriate to the atmosphere. Hatred also features a low, brooding sound track, that never over powers, but adds a ton to the mood. It also features a physics engine that is sure to impress, as gun fire breaks away the walls that surround you. It's a great looking game! But be aware, the game can be buggy at times with NPCs flipping out, cars floating in the air, and other weird oddities.

For all it's controversy, Hatred is not the worst on the market. Mortal Kombat is gorier, Hotline Miami is more violent, and Postal 2 was more psychotic. The ONLY thing that set Hatred apart from the other games mentioned is that you play as a the villain that takes place in a (some what) realistic world. Basically, Hatred is controversial by concept only, the content of the game really isn't even a quarter as disturbing as the media would have you believe.

Overall Hatred is a competent isometric shooter that has an edgy theme to it. The gameplay itself is nothing special or revolutionary but does the trick. The controversy surrounding this game is way overblown, and dosn't deserve the AO rating (M would be appropriate). At the end of the day, Hatred isn't bad, but it's nothing special either.

Pros:
- Great looking style
- Competent gameplay
- Challenging (Once the police shows up)

Cons:
- Does nothing new or special in terms of gameplay
- Shooting NPCs that don't fight back can get boring.

reviewText:
This game is laughably amateur. It rides 100% on the controversial nature of its content, and even thats a let down.

Lets start with the gameplay. Its boring. Quite possibly the worst twin-stick shooter I think ive ever played. Aiming in both normal and precise mode are floaty and inaccurate. Instead of a line pointing where your aiming you have a cross hair. Guess the devs dont realize its not a FPS and come to think of it this game would be a lot better if it where. Sure you can get an aiming line (In precise mode as I call it) but thats even worse, so much so that I never used it. In this mode you hold down the trigger that moves the camera away from your character to the area ahead. However the aiming in this mode is very twitchy. Combine this with the fact that this almost always leaves you unable to see your character leaving him open for attack.

The environments are ok I guess and I do like the destructible buildings, but you only get a few grenades and those are even more inaccurate and jerky then the guns. They try to go for this Sin city look with the black and white graphics but thats boring and sometimes a hindrance to gameplay as in dark areas you get stuck on things that are hard to see. For example in the second level you have to escape a sewer being swarmed by cops and SWAT teams. But more often then not its hard to see your enemies and if you fall in the watter your dead. You have to run to vault over things and you cant run in the water. So that leaves you moving slow till you can find a spot that you can walk out of the water. All the while your getting shot up by extremely dumb and unrealistic AI.

And the AI is some of the most basic and dumb AI I think ive ever seen. Cops just rush you, with no thought of cover or tactics. A cop will run up alone and just start shooting you despite the fact youve got a shotgun and mowing down everything. The SWAT teams arnt any better as they take an unrealistic amount of damage and zerg rush you like the flatfoots do. And the civilian AI is even dumber than the cops, acting like mice locked in a box with a cat.

So in closing let me say this, the game has potential but its not worth the 20 bucks.  Full Disclosure I diddnt finish the game and am taking advantage of Steams new refund policy. Its an OK game but should be 5 bucks not 20.

reviewText:
There areâ€¦certain games out there, which few of us like talking about. Brutal games. Shocking games. Games which earned age restrictions usually reserved for centenarians who are into ultra-porn. Only a handful of these games exist, and quite a few of them have earned their notorious ratings. Hatred is the newest contender to that throne, a game where human life is cheaper than your ex-girlfriend and bullets are plentiful. But for all its bluster and shock value, Hatred never becomes more than a game built on clever marketing and sometimes-capable gameplay.

If youâ€™ve been living under a rock or inside a church with a particularly solid internet firewall, then Hatredâ€™s story is pretty much easily summed as a kill-frenzy in shades of grey. Itâ€™s like playing through an extended version of the torture scenes from the 2005 Punisher video game, while your nihilistic antagonist spouts one-liners about culling the herd of humanity and how his retribution is justified.

A twin-stick shooter, Hatred allows you to pop rounds off on an innocent populace, stopping every now and again to ease their misery by introducing their heads to an AK47 round or the cold steel of your knife on their throat. No one can stop you, cops are unprepared for your suburban genocide and the more you execute the more you heal. Reading that, the game sounds horrific. Especially when you realise how good some people are at it, and how easy it becomes to commit mass murder later on. The thing is, all of this doesnâ€™t make the game any special.

Iâ€™ve seen bigger uproars over players kicking a cat in GTA V or minions begging for their lives before being sliced to ribbons in Ninja Gaiden 3. But to me, theyâ€™re nothing more than pixels and coding, coupled together with some voice-acting and command prompts. And hell, Iâ€™m all for the idea of a population-thinner of a game. Half the time I was playing Hatred, I was imagining that the people that I was slaughtering were the same folks who clog up entire passages in shopping malls or fail to comprehend the idea of a moving walkway at airports.

And on and on and on I killed. I worked my way through pedestrians, families, police stations, trains and a nuclear power station eventually. Holy crap, did it get boring quickly. Thereâ€™s no real sense of guilt in committing these atrocities in the game, no sense of well-placed emotional regret for offing a random civilian, even when the game does a close-up of the wicked deed. Thereâ€™s no emotional attachment whatsoever, as your cipher of a main character growls out clichÃ©d dialogue and goes to work.

Thereâ€™s also very little satisfaction, as the game made me feel numb. I genuinely didnâ€™t care. Technically, the game is alright. You run around, shoot and chuck explosives. Thatâ€™s the easy summation of the game. Targeting however, felt deliberately off at times, as players seem to only score enough hits to knock a civilian into a mercy-killing state, resulting in an inconsistent system of murder most foul.

Visually, the game has a few neat ideas. Taking place with a subdued palette of only black, white and grey, colour is reserved for more shocking or explosive moments in the game. It works as long as you arenâ€™t paying attention to the world around you, as the colour scheme often results in difficult scenarios where character blend into their surroundings too easily and making the game massively confusing as you seek to achieve your kill quota.

Itâ€™s justâ€¦I donâ€™t even know. The game feels comically underwhelming when you really sit back and examine it. At best, Hatred is an average game, dressed up in controversy. Itâ€™s not even close to being as horribly charming as Postal was almost two decades ago, nowhere near as funny as Bulletstorm was and about as shocking as a soap opera ending.

If youâ€™re looking for a certain thrill to accompany random acts of mass slaughter, youâ€™ll find it in plenty of other games on the market today. Controversy can only carry a game so far, before it trips itself up. Overall 5/10.

reviewText:
I'll admit from the start that I played this game for less than an hour because I couldn't bare it any more.

This is a mediocre game at best with the best marketing campaign in the world. It's marketed entirely on its subject matter, its controversy - but that is it. For the first few minutes the game is exhilarating while you're just thinking â€œHoly â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥! I'm actually playing a game where I massacre a neighbourhood full of people!â€. You throw grenades into a house party and massacre a funeral procession in a hail of bullets. But that quickly fades when you realise that the game is just that over and over.

The gameplay is dull, repetitive and boring. At times it feels borderline unplayable as the controls are clunky and difficult to the point of frustration - both with mouse and keyboard as they are with a controller.

Iâ€™m sure many people will disagree with me and thatâ€™s fine. Hatred might be exactly the game you are looking for. Iâ€™m reminded of all the controversy that used to come with PS2 era GTA games, but without the fantastic end product. For me, Hatred is a less than average game built up by controversy to sell more copies.

All I can say is thank god Steam refunds came when they did.

reviewText:
If Hatred was more fully devoted to being either a comedy or a drama, its narrative may have been more successful. As it is, the most fun to be had in the game comes almost entirely from the moments when the player breaks away from the mission structure and massacre everyone around without worrying about the context of its plot.

The game only has 7 parts but all of them offer great replay value.

The highlight of this game is mostly due to itself being very realistic. What I meant by realistic is that the AI in-game actually act like how real people do in the real world. The female AI of this game often tends to run away instead of fighting back even though they are brave feminists. The protecting forces of the game which consist of police offers, the SWAT team and also the army are all male, and never a single female, leaving all the men to die on their own. Just like in real life! Has it ever occurred to anyone that the engineer at the ending was a male instead of a female? Shocking truth!

What the game lacks is diversity. Every single one of the civilians that you can kill in game are mostly normal citizens with no special traits aside from the difference in their skin color. To make the game as realistic as possible, the developers should have added AI like feminists or Social Justice Warriors like what Postal did. Besides that, there should also be gays and lesbians making out on the street. This should have already been implemented with no question ask since hipsters and drug junkies have existed in game.

The achievements created in this game are quite interesting as they contain references to other games such as Grand Theft Auto, Postal and the Witcher series. As you can see on my profileâ€™s achievement page, I have gotten nearly every single Hatredâ€™s achievement, they are really easy to accomplish and are able to be unlocked from time to time as you progress in game. The only achievement which I am having trouble unlocking is the one called â€œFeministâ€. The objective to unlocking it is to kill 2000 men if I recall correctly. But sadly, I only shoot women. Due to this tough obstacle, I am unable to 100% the game. So I do hope they do something about it in the future as this achievement would also mark me as a feminist which I am not.

The game itself is not flawless but it clearly shows a promising future for a genre more like it to be produced and also be able to offer a lot of fun. Without a doubt this is the best open world shooting game in recent years. 9.5/10

reviewText:
A decently fun game gameplay-wise is hampered by poor optimization and/or coding, some dumb game design decisions (namely the prehistoric and infuriating respawn/restart system), and only being 4-5 hours long with no real replay value. Basically this game will be forgotten as quickly as it was released. The framerates in the 1st level are around 40-50 and the rest of the game is around 35-45, usually around 40 during all the action. Of course it sucks, but was actually tolerable enough for this style of game to play through once. This game brings nothing new to the table & has zero mission variety (100% of missions are go here, kill X amount of ppl). The game is very hard even on easy, and I only beat it in normal time (around 4 hours) because I have enough skill as a gamer to bunker down and get it done.

Some things to point out:
The difficulty spikes hard in the military base level when you get swarmed by military guys and just get shot down immediately, and that's even on easy. You can only beat it by being extremely careful and picking everyone off with long-aim fire. The respawn system is infuriating because say you have 2 respawns and you use them, you have to do the ENTIRE level over again... uhg. It's the same system games from 10-12 years ago used because technology didn't allow most games yet to have checkpointing. And on that level you die incredibly easy after you pick up the C4 and start making your way back through newly spawned guys who mow you down from off-screen, erasing the very careful 45 minutes of work I just did. I had to backtrack several times to replenish armor and at one point hide in a room and let the ignorant AI walk in one by one and pick them off that way. The shotgun is absolutely worthless after level 1 because it fires and reloads too slow and only holds 6 shells. It also can take 3 shots to down one guy if he has armor on. The shooting system is good but is made unnecessarily harder by the poor framerate. It makes your aiming somewhat slower like the game is in slow motion when all enemies have pinpoint accuracy and you can get swarmed and downed in seconds. Ducking and popping out of cover to fire is your best friend. Although there is no crouch toggle so you have to hold down crouch and mouse 2 to far aim and release crouch briefly to pop up and fire. Another problem is that sometimes things like rope sections in the train station for instance are similar in color to the floor so you get snagged on obstacles you can't really see while trying to get out of a room and just get shot down in a couple seconds by the military and cops. It happens a lot with other floor obstacles as well because you can't really see them, a lot of times also because the isometric view blocks a lot of stuff from view. I don't care how good a game is, I don't want to have to repeat an entire level because the developers for some â™¥â™¥â™¥-brained reason decided to have a half-baked respawn system. It makes no sense and just makes it a chore to repeat entire levels in a average-at-best game.

Some things about the game design are insanely stupid. Cars are drive-able but you never, ever want to be even anywhere near them because they catch fire and explode after only a few bullets hit them. Even armored army vehicles with mounted guns explode in a few bullet hits. The game is already pretty unrealistic but something like that should not for any reason be a part of a game. A lot of bullets exploding cars sure, why not, but not only a slight few. Cars irl are designed to not explode anyway. It's just plain brainless game design. I have gotten stuck between a garbage can and a tree when there is what should be a clear path between them. In the military base level they start you out in a army suv with a mounted gun. It is useless since it explodes in a few seconds, that is until you figure out how to ease forward then get back on the gun to kill a few more guys. The level is near impossible even on easy unless you spend the whole time aiming and killing from a distance with mouse 2. Even then it is still exceptionally easy to be swarmed out of nowhere and die quickly. Executions for health gain can be impossible to pull off when on levels like the military base bullets are hitting you from every possible angle. The game on easy mode is equal to what most other games are on their hardest modes. You can be shot from guys far off screen, farther than you can see even with long distance aiming. He's on the roof!" a citizen yells about me when I am in the street. People can clip through walls while on the ground making execution animations blocked from view because your guy clips through it too to reach the person

reviewText:
There's not much to say about Hatred, mainly because there is not much to do in Hatred. This game was wonderfully advertised for its controversy which is what has made the game so popular in the first place, but if only their ability to build hype was as good as their ability to build a decent game. If maybe a bit of extra thought or purpose was given to the game it might hold it's own a little, but shortly after the opening few minutes you have already done everything that you can.

Graphically, the game has quite a nice gritty visual style which holds up in my opinion; the ability to smash through the destructible environments is a nice a touch. The violence, in terms of blood and gore, is actually fairly tame in comparison to many games that I have played which recieved nowhere near as much controversy. I guess context is probably what puts it into the AO ranks, though personally I don't think it deserves a rating that high; getting it an AO rating only surged its media publicity as being one of the few games to earn that rank.

All in all, this game shocked me, not because of it's pointless violence, frustrating controls (especially with a keyboard) and lack of any narrative at all, but just because it was boring and lacking in any substance at all. I'm all for video games being an open and free platform for people to create whatever they want in anyway they want to, but I am not for this game being used as an example for that statement as there is much more out there from Indie studios who deserve the publicity for a game that inspires further creativity and something positive.

reviewText:
IntroductionAh, Hatredâ€¦ the game that was first in the progress of being greenlit, then quickly removed by Valve because it was deemed too controversial and then finally re-added (with some sort of apology). Given the history and success of controversial games like Grand Theft Auto and Carmageddon that can only be a good thing, right? Wellâ€¦, not always apparently.

GameplayWhile games like Grand Theft Auto and Carmageddon actually introduced some new - or at least improved â€“ ideas to their genres, despite being controversial, this unfortunately doesnâ€™t apply to Hatred. In reality Hatred is just another isometric action game. Here are some of the reasons why:

The story is straightforward, and not very deep: you had it with society and then just decide to murder everyone around you, unleashing Armageddon. You will start at your own home and then work your way through the city of New York. There sometimes are smaller, more linear levels where you have to just escape and move to the next place. But not without killing some people in the progress, of course.
Now, I havenâ€™t yet finished the game but I think Iâ€™ve seen enough of it to write a review. Unless thereâ€™s something that changes up the gameplay drastically 3/4th into the game, I think the review should be quite accurate.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527952570
Since the style is meant to be realistic you wonâ€™t find any weird, fantasy weaponry in this game. You will, for example, use pistols, shotguns, machine guns and several types of grenades in your quest to wipe every man and woman off of the face of the earth. As expected, you will be able to find better, more powerful weapons later in the game where you have to face more and tougher enemies.
In order to not get hurt you can always try to hide behind and inside buildings and other solid objects (enemies will sometimes try to do the same) but this is no guarantee to not get hurt because enemies often come from all sides and the bullets can literally fly anywhere you look.
Speaking of enemies: the difficulty seems to randomly spike up at times. What seemed so easy at first somehow instantly becomes hard(er). I encountered this several times during my sessions and I donâ€™t think itâ€™s me (but hey, I might not know myself as well as I thought).

Wounded people can also be executed which will (partially) restore your health bar. Later on in the game they will become harder to pull off, though. This is due to the fact you have to keep a careful eye on your surroundings as more and more enemies will appear and they will also take more damage before they die. Plus, you still can get shot while executing someone.
Still, itâ€™s a cool concept and the fact that the game sometimes switches to a third person view (showing the killing in much more detail) keeps the game from becoming too much of a borefest.

I do think the camera is a little too close to the character. At times it certainly wouldâ€™ve been nice if we could zoom in or out ourselves to get a better overview of whatâ€™s happening and where. The minimap generally does a good job at trying to show you this information, but Iâ€™m afraid that it sometimes isnâ€™t enough and you just want to see things for yourself.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527952620
There are also vehicles at your disposal, like police cars and SWAT cars. However, they wonâ€™t be of much use to you since the controls are just horrible. You have to use the left stick to gas and brake (pushing forward and backward) and the right stick to steer left and right. Sounds easy, right? Nope. I think people will eventually get used to them, but theyâ€™re anything but intuitive. I guess the reason for this is because otherwise you would drive just around creating havoc and as a result it might make the game (a little) easier.

Technically the game is more than okay, but the framerate does fluctuate regularly. This might be because of the implemented physics system because otherwise I have no idea what could be causing it. Itâ€™s not the most technically advanced game Iâ€™ve ever played so maybe with some extra months of polishing we wouldâ€™ve been able to play it with a rock solid framerate. A missed opportunity.

Audio & VisualsThe songs are generally what you would expect in a game like this: itâ€™s hard - metal-like - music and it fits the mood just perfectly. The sound effects are solid, too, and the voice acting ranges from okay to mediocre, but given everything that might just be a good thing. It certainly keeps things lighter, although it remains a very bleak game nevertheless.

Ah yes, the graphicsâ€¦ This is where the game really shines and Iâ€™m not being sarcastic here. As you can see by looking at the screenshots everything is shown in black and white, while other elements (blood, some types of lights and explosions, for example) still show up in their original colors. If youâ€™ve ever seen Sin City then you have a good idea of how it will look. Everything is nicely detailed and animated, except for some of the faces, but this is usually only seen up close when the game switches to the third person view and is therefore not a big deal. Overall itâ€™s a very good looking game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=527952644
Length/Replay ValueI never expected to say this, but as you can see I became bored about 3/4th into the game. Itâ€™s by no means a terrible or bad game, but it all becomes repetitive way too soon, resulting into boredom. Then again, I guess thatâ€™s what one should expect from a game in this genre. Iâ€™ve been told the game lasts about 4-5 hours and if you play on Extreme you can expect it to be twice that figure.
So ultimately not very long but long enough. I might finish it up later, but for now Iâ€™ve seen enough.

ConclusionHatred certainly looked interesting the first time I saw it in motion and I was definitely intrigued by all the controversy. After having played it myself I can hereby tell you that theyâ€™ve created a good, but still very repetitive and shallow action game. I think the developer tried too hard to create something controversial that - in combination with the depressing tone and setting - ends up looking unique and pretty, but at the same time is just not very much fun to play.
Grab it to see what itâ€™s all about, but, unless youâ€™re a hardcore action game lover, itâ€™s recommended to wait for a sale.

Too long, didnâ€™t readPros:
+ Visually beautiful
+ Some big open levels
+ Side objectives

Mixed:
+/- Random difficulty spikes
+/- While most of the controls work fine Iâ€™d have rather seen a different/better control scheme for choosing weapons (with the controller)
+/- Wouldâ€™ve been nice if we could manually zoom in and out

Cons:
- Vehicle controls are absolutely terrible
- Shallow gameplay
- The tone is a little too serious and this results in the game not being any real fun (only in shorter sessions maybe)
- Performance issues

Please note: a Steam key for this game was provided by the developer.
Rating: 6.0 (out of 10)(Ratings arenâ€™t calculated based on a formula, but on my personal feelings)

reviewText:
Hatred is a pretty fun game to play, it takes a mission or two to get the feel of the controls and figure out where the hell your crosshair is sometimes but other than that the aesthetics and gameplay are fun and great if you want to play something carnage-ridden and violently entertaining.

I would say this is a good game but if this is it's final form then I believe I cannot properly give it a complete OK.

The main problem is the respawns and restarting the game. I haven't died very much until the military base mission and it's already started to get on my nerves, it's not so much a 'git gud' feel to this feature but more to make the player get angry and quit playing. And for having to restart a hard mission four times without getting a chance to respawn, playing each time for about 15 to 30 minutes and trying hard to survive, I just stopped the game.

I want this to be a good game, and gameplay wise it's nice, but with this feature it ruins the experiance for me.

Another thing, kicking at enemy S.W.A.T members or soldiers seems to do nothing, and they just keep shooting you or your character misses. They don't even stumble they just keep shooting at you and it really tears up your health if you're seeking them out for a well-deserved execution for more health, but instead they just kill you. To me this appears as more of a gameplay flaw than it being intended to happen and it's really discerning.

Now most of these problems would be problems if it weren't for the respawn issue, but as far as I have seen those are the primary issues. If there happens to have no future moddable features, map builders, potential multiplayer if you ever consider it, I would not recommend it. In it's current form it puts me on the fence, but recommending this on steam is through generosity and the fact it's fun to play, also because of external factors not relating to the game but moreso media and it's cultural marxist-esque deviants that crawl out of their hole of a basement every once and a while to spew garbage from their mouths as useful idiots, even though they still are just on the internet.

So thanks for the game, it feels like it needs a couple more tweaks to the features, future features and such and a HUGE THANKS to stepping up to media, intellectuals and SJW's alike.

reviewText:
Hatred is a game thatâ€™s popularity is solely based on its edgy concept, brutal violence, and adults only rating. And that may be enough to some people. But Hatred has way too many problems to be considered worth 20 bucks.

(If you donâ€™t want to read my entire rant, there will be a list of the overall problems with this game at the bottom or the review)

Hatredâ€™s gameplay is almost non-existent. Itâ€™s a duel stick shooter, where the objective is to kill anyone and everyone because our protagonist, named Not Important, hates everyone and everything for no stated reason. The appeal of a no holds barred killing spree is a fairly large one, the popularity of GTA and other open world sandbox games have proven that. But this game flops due to its repetitive nature. The entire game is shoot everything and occasionally press Y to do a poorly animated finishing move. Thatâ€™s the game.

Besides being just plain boring, the controls are janky and hard to do anything with, and the game switches between â€œâ™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ easyâ€ and â€œRun the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ away or die hardâ€. Not to mention that the framerate is absolute garbage if you donâ€™t lower the graphics to a point where the game looks like â™¥â™¥â™¥, and the monochromatic styling of the game makes everything just generally harder to see.

Mr. Important is also not winning any acting awards anytime soon. The point of the gameâ€™s existence is to be as dark and disturbing as physically possible. Not Important manages to not just kill the people, but to kill the mood as well. The man is hilarious! Heâ€™s a walking talking teenage edge machine! Everything he says is either about how much he likes killing people, or swear words (usually both), and itâ€™s all in the darkest, most gravelly voice that I have ever heard. The man has no character, he doesnâ€™t have a personality, he doesnâ€™t have a backstory, and he doesnâ€™t have ANYTHING that could make him a real person. The man isnâ€™t scary because heâ€™s so over the top and unrealistic.

And the game isnâ€™t even good on its â€œEXTREME VIOLENCEâ€ selling point. When the people youâ€™re killing scream, they rarely sound convincing enough for you to actually think theyâ€™re real people youâ€™re taking the lives of. And when they do, Not Important ruins the atmosphere by saying edgy â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ to himself. The blood and damage you inflict on people are hilariously bad. When you shoot someone in the face with one of your pre-animated finishing moves, your victimâ€™s face looks like what happens when you shoot a gmod ragdoll in the face. No splatter, no hole in the head, no blood running from your victimâ€™s skull. Just a gmod blood mark. If you donâ€™t know what that looks like, just google â€œgmod bloodâ€ and go to images, itâ€™s hilarious. And when you stab someone in your finishing move, I donâ€™t think there is any blood at all, I know for a fact you donâ€™t leave stab marks. Your knife literally just clips through them to death. The death effects might be better with the graphics up, I doubt it, but even if it was, it doesnâ€™t matter because the framerate was chugging with the gameâ€™s default graphics setting! My computer may not be the best, but it sure as hell should be able to handle a gameâ€™s default graphics setting! I donâ€™t even think this should be an adults only game. Besides the concept alone, and Not Important occasionally dropping the C-bomb, this game isnâ€™t THAT bad. Itâ€™s even tamer then some M for mature games Iâ€™ve seen.

And thatâ€™s what really disappoints me, the fact that itâ€™s not that bad! If it had repetitive gameplay, janky controls, horrible characters, but did the one thing that it advertised really well, I would have considered it a decent game that delivers what it promises. If it was more brutal, more gory, more disturbing, it would have done what it wanted to accomplish!
But as the game is now, Iâ€™d pay 5 bucks for it. But as a 20 game, itâ€™s just not worth it.

Things I disliked about hatred:
-Too expensive
-Boring and repetitive gameplay
-Bad Framerate/ bad graphics
-Protagonist you canâ€™t take seriously
-Not brutal enough
-Janky controls
-Lack of any story or motive
-Many clipping and camera bugs

reviewText:
I'm new to twin-stick shooters, so I have little to compare this against so take my review with a grain of salt but:

1) There is no story to speak of.  If you are still interested after reading this then this may be for you.
2) The keyboard controls are spot-on.  The controls with an XBOX-One controller are a little odd at first, but get intuitive really quick.
3) The production quality is really good.  You can tell from the execution scenes that the whole gave is actually 3d, but outside of cutscenes and executions the camera stays in a 3/4 perspective, which works well.  I also like the horror movie vibe from the background sounds and grainy video effect.
4) There is no story.

I'm enjoying it, but wouldn't recommend it for anyone expecting a rewarding experience.  If you just want a mindless distraction, then this is for you.

reviewText:
Listen to me... I love this game, I never get bored of watching that physics engine in action and since the last update (2nd June) the performance is MUCH better for me so plays a lot better (I'm running i7 5930K and GTX780 at time of writing).

The game is pretty hard, taken me an hour just to get to level 2 but thats fine I enjoy the challenge. The AI needs some work to be fair but the visual style they went for works perfectly, black and white noir style with some limited colours from things like police car lights.

Yes the game is quite limited, only a few weapons types, no level up or upgrade paths but who cares.. thats not the game its trying to be, runing and gunning, thats all you need. The controls are pretty simple, of course as a PC gamer i prefer K/M but dont seem to have any problems.. the run / drop kicks are pretty fun.

I've also heard some people aren't to happy with the checkpoint save system... but it seems pretty fair to me. in fact, Renegade ops uses pretty much the same method but no one seem to question that? (you do start with the lives rather than earning them but lose them all and you gotta start the whole level again too).

I can see why a lot of people would get bored and the content is limited but listen, I'm a BIG fan of the first postal game and this plays just like that.. better even.. Devs have done a great job and look forward to what else they can bring to the gaming table in the future.

In closing, I feel that a lot of people are being negative about this game just because of the whole issue with the media plus the fact most people on the interwebz are a$$holes and not really judging the game itself which isn't fair... so my comments today are to help even up the playing field and to recommend it based on the game itself and not on the controversy that surrounds it.

reviewText:
This game desperately wants to be the 2015 answer to 1997's edgy kill-em-all, Postal.  It plays and looks like a direct homage, and it even directly borrows audio assets from it.  But this game is no Postal.  Thing is, I LOVED Postal when it came out.  I still do, actually.  It's mindless violence, but there's a satire to it.  I feel like maybe the creators were going for satire, and failed miserably?  I'm not sure.  It feels like the crass fantasies of basement dwelling â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ners angry at the world for no reason.   This game was just desperate garbage.

For me, the main thing that separates Hatred from Postal is the objective.  In Postal, your goal is to kill the authority figures.  The Man, trying to keep you down.  Cops, military, etc.  They're trying to kill you, and you try to kill them.  CAN you kill innocents?  Most definitely.  As much as you like, violently.  But that's your own sickness.  The game never tells you to kill innocent people.  In Hatred, killing innocents IS THE GOAL.  The authority figures trying to kill you?  They don't matter.  They're a hindrance, an obstacle between you and murdering innocent people, nothing more.  This game just wants you to murder, and rather than feeling dark and gritty, it feels desperate, like some skinny goth teenager trying so hard to convince people he's scary and dangerous, when we all know his wardrobe came from Hot Topic when his mom dropped him off at the mall.

On a technical level, the game is fine.  Plays pretty smoothly, graphics are decent, art style is kind of cool.  It did crash on me at one point, I don't know why.   You'll want to mess with the keybindings; they're a little awkward.

But honestly, just ignore this one.  It's not worth the controversy, and not worth your time.

reviewText:
If this game was fixed and ironed out a lot more,  before its release.  It would of been the fun death sim I was hoping and waiting for.
I was hoping for a game that was a similar experience, to the likes of the PlayStation exclusive of dead nation.  Perhaps, another great Miami hotline 2 type game ?
After seeing those trailers and gameplay vids on YouTube, taking a gamble to purchase the game and see what its like first hand for myself. Here are my personal thoughts and opinions so far about Hatred.

Here is the deal, I wanted to like and enjoy the game of Hatred. The problem is that the game is fun until it lags like hell with severe dips and frame rate issues.  I hear they fixed it with patches.  Yet still not fixed i have noticed ?   Perhaps a bit, since I read from other forums that the control support and some lag issues had been delt and addressed.  The funny thing is that this can be fixed easily with the lags concerned. I can see the potential idea this game has.  It just feels unfinished, unpolished with some horrible dips and lags issues, especially during execution sequences and cutscenes.

The only good things about this game, is the weapons feel brutal when you shoot people in the game.  It has lovely effects and explosion nd destructive sounds.  You can even enter vehicles
The execution cutscences are pretty sickeningly cool.  Even though, sometimes when it takes like 15 seconds to come out during the frame rate issues. ??

My conclussion :

Fix these issues and the game is fun to play, no doubt.  It does borrow a bit from Dead Nation and Miami Hotline which is fine. This can not be a bad thing but its develpers, just feels like they rushed the game way too quickly.
The character you play is just an upleasant, vile person, that has a troubled day, being in a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ mood.  After smoking too much cannibis, avoiding his anti-depressants, then blaming other people and the world for the way he lives.  So he then basically wants eliminate all other human beings, pretty much.
He just doesnt seem interesting and the story does not seem to capture the magic for his reason to just murder innocent victims.  It needs more back up.  The detail is nice but a lot is missing.

6/10

Nice idea but fix and it will get a thumbs up and a reccomedation to a 7/10.

Thanks for taking your time to read.

Eh...meh?
That's really my short response to it.

I wish there was a thumbs in the middle option. Hatred at the moment has some optimization issues, it's LITERALLY Postal: 2015 (the first one not the 2nd one). I don't know what people were expecting this game to be:

-A barbaric experience that fuels the edgy kids who still live with their mom? Kinda.

It does what it needs to do, but it doesn't go more than that. Hatred is just a simple twin-stick shooter that got very lucky with its controversy due to media outrage and people wanting to buy it to prove a point (about...something).


Wait for a sale if you're mildly interested. Maybe by then there will be a couple patches that fix the frame rates and some crashes that people are reporting. I don't hate the game, but I'm not seeing the massive hype/controversy that surrounds it.
