reviewText:
Hatred is a Twin stick shooter in which we take on the role of a mass murder, in his mission to â€œcleanse the worldâ€ from humanity. To accomplish this he, well actually he has no plan whatsoever and just goes from area to area, killing random people by the droves. As you may imagine this doesn't sit too well with the local police force and they will soon set out confront him in a shoot out. Unfortunately for them, our nameless antagonist has the power to regenerate his wounds by brutality finishing off any wounded people. How much he regenerates is based on what difficulty level you chose. Regardless of that strange power, our player character is not an all mighty death dealer and is actually pretty fragile. A couple of shots is all it takes to kill you, so it is best to fight crouched and with suitable cover, especially when some of the tougher enemies show up. Don't rely on it too long though, cover is destructible and will soon be a pile of rubble from all the bullet holes.

To fight back you will be able to carry up to three weapons and some grenades, however the flash-bang grenades are near useless. Your ammo supply will be very limited and the only way to get more is to resupply from the weapons of the recently deceased. Whole levels may be lacking a certain type of ammo for one of your weapons, in which case it is best to swap it out for one that is easily found throughout the level. Unfortunately, you will see most of the weapons this game has to offer in no time and they are all pretty generic. There is one shotgun, one handgun, one assault rifle, along with a few other weapons. Since this game is purely about killing, it does get old very quickly. There is no melee whatsoever minus an epic flying kick, to down people for an easy execution. The knife our character is carrying is pure show and only appears during the cut-scene animations of a execution. Bullet proof armor is also in this game and will double the amount of damage you take if you are lucky enough to find one.

The previously mentioned executions are the main source of controversy in this title, as they show a close up, brutal execution of a pleading victim. Funnily enough they are not even that violent compared to other games and due to the few execution animations there are, will quickly lose their shock value.  Remember how I mentioned that this is the only way to regain health? Yeah, I have no idea how the devs thought this would be a good idea since you will be seeing these over and over again, causing a ton of breaks in the action just to see the same execution pulled off time and time again. To make matters worse, time doesn't freeze when you enter an execution cut-scene, so as soon as you finish killing the victim to regain health, you will find yourself surrounded by heavily armed enemies then will be quickly gunned down. You do have an option to turn off execution cutscenes, which you will want to do as quickly as possible, but that kind of destroys the main gimmick of Hatred.

About 2 of the 7 levels are throw away romps, through linear uninspired environments like a  sewer or a train. The rest feature a small, open world environment to cause havoc in, as well as multiple side quests. These side quests always need you to kill someone or destroy something, which we probably would have done anyways, but you will definitely want to head straight for them as completing one will net you a token that allows you to respawn if you were to die. You will also be able to drive around these environments with a very specific vehicle, which is usually a police car. Unless that vehicle has a mounted machine gun it is completely pointless to get into one of these, since the controls for driving are abysmal and they take very little damage before exploding. Your character takes his sweet time to get out of a burning vehicle as well, so walking is nearly always the safer option. In case you are wondering, no you can not shoot out of your car window, you will be completely defenseless. There are no maps of the areas and some are strangely laid out, so cars are purely a gimmick. One thing I would like to mention is that our character has no qualms with killing random people, but he will not steal a parked car for whatever reason.

Environments look great. Hatred is powered by Unreal Engine 4 and it is the best looking twin stick shooter on the market. From the amount of detail in areas to the limited destructibility of everything via gunfire or explosives, it is a truly impressive. It's a very demanding game however, my frame-rate dipped to the 30's on a fairly high end PC. Ironically enough the very same attention to detail placed in the environments severely harm the game. There are just too many objects that impede your movement and will stop you dead in your tracks in vital moments. Your character can vault over some objects while sprinting, but it is a clunky, unreliable system that feels barely functional. A lot of buildings are designed in a way that makes it have plenty of dead ends , causing you to backtrack, which will be your doom if your objective was to flee from your pursuers. You can jump out of windows with the sprint key, but good luck getting that to work correctly. Some areas have multiple vertical layers which absolutely breaks the AI until they are on the same plane as you. They can not shoot up and you can not shoot down, so it comes down to waiting for them to figure out their way to you so you can kill them.

Plenty of missions require you to kill a certain amount of innocents and that gets old fast. The number required just gets too high and becomes extremely repetitive, not to mention counter productive, as slaying all the civilians will get rid of all your easy targets for a health refill. It's not fun either, they are all bullet spongy and it's total waste of ammo. They can take several assault rifle rounds before they go down and with actual trained combatants it feels like we are fighting cyborgs or something. Civilians are not defenseless however, they will frequently pick up weapons and fire at you. Problem with that is they are equally as skilled with that weapon as a trained soldier, only difference being the amount of damage they can take. It really breaks the illusion of them being victims when they all know how to operate a machine gun and are fearlessly fighting along side soldiers, to the death. That could have been cool, seeing a few people go all John Rambo on you, though seeing them endlessly pull more ammo out of there pocket and refusing to flee no matter what, time and time again is just plain weird. Enemy AI also have the ability to see you through solid walls and will no your position at all times. Cops just appear out of thin air instead of closing in on you and everything just feels badly designed.

Survival mode is what saves this game. It throws away Hatred's inconsistent sense of realism and places you in unique small maps specifically designed to fight in.  The environments in these allow for much more fluid movement than the cluttered messy environments in story mode.  You will be able to pick from three different characters that appear after the aftermath of the end of story mode and all have different stats. Instead of the boring ambient music of story mode, you will have the option of playing an awesome heavy metal track in these maps. After each wave you will be able to buy explosives, ammo or body armor with the points you gain from killing as well as gaining experience to increase in rank. The higher your rank, the more perks, weapons and weapon slots you can access. This mode is a decent amount of fun and shows you the difference of designing a game around the gameplay, over how much edge you can cram into a series of dull, pointless objectives like in story mode. This is a weird one to recommend. If the subject matter does not bother you, this is a mediocre twin stick shooter that will kill a few hours.

reviewText:
I did not enjoy hatred very much. The first thing I have to say is there is a serious lack of weapon variety. For the type of game it is, one would expect a wide variety of weaponry at your disposal. I would expect somewhere between 40-60 weapons, seeing how this game is focused entirely on killing people. There are about 13 I would estimate. Many of which you will hardly get the chance to use. you will only be using the weapons your enemies are currently using, because it is nearly impossible to find ammo for any other weapons.

I must point out a large problem with the game, in the nicest way possible. The controls are absolute â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.They basically ruin the game. A large portion of this issue is the camera. The â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing camera. It fought me and won throughout my whole experience. I constantly found myself tryin to shoot a soldier just out of view, as the camera fought back the whole time, trying to re-center my character as I was being riddled with bullets. As of the time of this review, they have lowered the attack range of the soldiers to make this issue less lethal to your character, however it would have been a much better idea to make the camera work.

Now on to the gameplay, when everything is working fine for the moment, It is average I suppose. The best thing I have to say is that it is actually difficult. That is very rare in games made today. You really dont feel like a badass though. I constantly find myself running around looking for a civillian to kill, becuase after about 3 seconds of heavy combat you are nearly dead. And furthermore, During combat you are always going to be trying to merely wound most of your enemies, (which if I might add, is strangely hard to do) so that you may execute them for health. Becuase trust me you are going to be needing to execute someone every â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing second. It is a interesting mechanic, But such an essential mechanic that there are very few satisfying moments where you can just gun down 15 or so people.

overall, the concept of a game focusing only on killing people has a lot of potential for interesting gameplay, but it was poorly executed in hatred. From one to ten, I would give this game A four.

reviewText:
Hatred only has controversy going for it. The black and white graphics are ugly and makes seeing targets a nightmare. The game runs poorly. Aiming is awkward (but not for the cops who shoot at you!). You can't revel in destruction, because ammo is limited and there's even a loading screen tip telling you the save your rifle ammo for cops. That might have been okay if you had a machete or something, but no, you end up having to JUMPKICK victims which is as ridiculous as it sounds.

Despite being a game about a spree killer, it feels like the devs actually avoided controversial elements as much as possible - there are no kids (even the old 2D Fallout games let you kill kids!), no religious elements (i.e. asking victims if they believe in God), no political agenda, no targeting of specific groups, no torture, no nothing.

One of my most memorable gaming experiences was a level of Cannon Fodder where you had to blow up several bases that kept spawning enemies. The only way to blow them up was with a cannon in the middle of the level, but if you tried to use the cannon, the enemy's bazooka guys would blow you up. So first you had to go around the whole level and kill every bazooka guy. After all that trouble, it was very satisfying to hop into the cannon and easily blast every base. THAT is how a game about a spree killer should work - killing helpless victims isn't challenging, so it isn't fun by itself, so it needs to be the REWARD after you've accomplished the game's real challenges. I mean, how great would it have been to play as the Hatred guy BEFORE the rampage? Imagine you're buying nails and fertilizer at the hardware store, and the cashier makes some crack about how happy is that you're finally going to fix up your busted eyesore of a house, and he can't wait to see the final product!" I mean
date: how much more satisfying would it be to blow up his store with a pipebomb then? SO much more!"

reviewText:
Hatred is about a man with a mission.

It is the year 2015.5 and the world has lost all its color. Now it is up to Not Important and his best friend, the AK-47 named Mindy, to embark on a perilous quest to restore the brightness and rainbows to the world.

Will they succeed in their task, or will the endless hordes of black-and-white disoriented minions of monotony prevail? Will Not Important restore the brightness to the world? Will Mindy ever accept that her usefulness is rather short-lived after the first level? Can Not Important realize that perhaps his aim would be better without that absolutely fabulous mane getting in the way? And will our heroes run out of Linkin Park songs before the mission is over?

Find out the answer to all these questions and more by delving into the magical world of Hatred, where friendship is shared with the pressing of Q on your keyboard, and monologues on the worthlessness of life are spoken with the worst sore throat since the time of Batman.

12/10 Would Hate Again.

reviewText: Hatred needs no introduction cause everyone knows about it since now. But will you want to see what the whole noise was about ? In Hatred we play as an unnamed man who hates the entire human population and wants to cleanse it, so he picks up a gun and massacres anyone that stands in his way. So how is Hatred ? Well it's bad. I'm not gonna judge the game by it's content. The game is just bad plain and simple. I was at first liking the entire thing. Shooting was really fun. Running around gunning everyone down while police try to stop you but just simply can't. The game looks nice, the lighting effects and the destruction are all quite impressive but the good stops there. The game starts to get boring after a couple levels cause there is no variations. You just simply run and gun until the game ends. The story is not there. There is no motivation to finish the game. The script is also hilarious when the main character spews one liners which are so over the top it's quite amusing. The executions are brutal but half of the time you won't get to see them for the camera spinning around and if the civilians glitch through walls. The game also has a massive difficulty spike when soldiers show up which are too tough to handle since they have armor and machine guns which kill you almost instantly. Overall the controversy surrounding the game was just there to sell the copies cause the game is really disappointing. Only get this game on a sale or otherwise skip it entirely. I give Hatred a 4.5/10

reviewText:
Stylish dark/noir arcade shoot'em up. Very nice graphics, animation and effects. Simple but addictive run and gun, and dodge and aim. Each level seems fairly open with a degree of exploration and side missions.

Gameplay consists of exploring varied environments such as a town, sewers, wilderness, moving train cars, in a 3D isometric style 3rd person perspective, using radar to find and eliminate the vast majority of denizens of any given place. You can carry 3 guns + 3 types of grenades, have limited ammo, can also sprint, dodge roll, and kick people within proximity to stun them or kill them.

The level of detail and fluidity in the graphics and animation is what we should have expected from something like Wasteland 2. I would love to see a mod turning Hatred into an action RPG shooter, or somat.

I'd say the game could take a $5 drop in price, considering it does become a bit repetitive, although its fun to play a level or two at a time without becoming too fatigued.

reviewText:
Hatred is an average top down shooter that will only cater to a niche market of players who enjoy repetitious gameplay or are hard into the original postal. If you are a huge fan of the original postal give it a try otherwise you might want to skip this title. I personally found the game enjoyable but the short length and poor optimization (since corrected on my machine in patch 3) hinder the experience.

If you do plan on picking it up I reccomend you wait until it goes on sale, at $20 the price point is quite steep considering it is only three hours long. $10 would be the ideal price point for this title.

Pros:
- Extremely well done levels/enviroment
- Enviroment is highly destructable
- Enjoyable but run of the mill combat
- Cops and Soldiers have a decent AI

Cons:
- Requires a bleeding edge 4+ core CPU for good performance making it inaccessable to many.
- Repetitive
- Extremely short
- God awful car controls

I would give it a 6/10, if co-op and mod support are added as planned it would be about a 7/10. I reccomend this only for people who meet said niche outlined above. In order to run this game decently you will need a high end multicore cpu, with at least four cores due to the intense resource drain caused by the physics system.

reviewText: Hatred is not an objectively bad game.  It looks good (both technically and aestically IMO), has a great atmospheric soundtrack, nice animations and one of the best destruction systems in gaming period.  Its also got a solid challenge; it's not just shooting fish in a barrel like some were thinking.  If you can look past the controversy and see it for what it is you might enjoy it.  Seriously though, they're pixel and not people....  Playing this won't turn you into a serial killer and I personally don't find shame in enjoying its gameplay.  I almost feel like after the censorship campaign failed against Hatred, that then people felt the need to crap all over it for being a bad game in general.  I find this pretty pathetic because as I said it's not objectively bad.  It's not perfect though.  Optimization is questionable (1440p, max IQ is using 100% from a GTX 980 with framerate dips into the 30 range), the story" is paper thin and the ending is abrupt.  But it's also a $20 indie game so your expectations should be adjusted accordingly.  I think 6-7 out of 10 is reasonable for the game.  There are a number of critically well received games that are flat out broken especially with the popularity of early access. So there will be lots of blood and lots of dead bodies.

It is quite disturbing really...  But not enough to stop me from playing the game. :)

reviewText: Well. This game is really misunderstood. Its metaphors and stuff. Subtle. Very subtle. It LOOKS like you are playing a complete psychopath that has finally gone berserk and started killing everyone and everything. But its the BURIED TRUTH behind his gaze that I find most compelling. What happened? WHY? I listen to his dialog for clues, and slowly, a deep tale of misguided masculinity and once good intentions gone astray begins to emerge, as the protagonist struggles with a world gone mad. The gameplay is solid, as you run around, guiding his wounded soul on a journey of healing and catharsis.  Sometimes the terrain is difficult to navigate, symbolic of today's confusing world. Its a steal for a mere $20. In short, its an amazing action game filled with gun play, explosions, and fully destructible environments, but on another level, it is a deep emotional tale of old fashioned masculinity searching for a place and self expression in a modern world of over indulgence and leisure.

reviewText: I went in expecting an increibly fun, sadistic, and over the top isometric shooter. Hatred delivers exactly that. The game is somewhat difficult even on easy, but once you get the hang of gunpay it becomes second nature. The destruction is beautiful, my jaw dropped the fist time I kicked in the door of a house and subsequently threw a high explosive grenade in the living room. Walls can be shot through, most cover can be destroyed, and Michael Bay seems to have left all of his extra set pieces lying around the levels which adds a lot to the destruction. Gunplay feels wonky at first, I definitely wouldn't recommend with a controller, but as I said I had no problem using corners and doorways and windows for cover once I figured it out (Shooting through walls to make murder holes for yourself is great too). I beat the game in 3-4 hours on easy, but even though I had most of the sidequests" I still wanted to see more. How many limbs can I take off with one shotgun shell? How many cars can I daisy chain together in an explosion? These qusetions I was yearning to find the answer to. I have kept playig once in a while (Yeah I know its been out 10 days) and it has still been fun as hell to cause mayhem. The levels are massive and have a lot to them
date: exploration via murder spree is a fun part of the game. Lots of goodfies lying around for those who do like to wander around.\n\nEverything considered

reviewText: Not worth the money. The executions are okay, but the gameplay is repetetive and a little dull as a result, and the really bland colour scheme makes it difficult to discern what's going on sometimes and can lead to annoying deaths when you're trying to escape the feds and you can't see you're running into a fence because it's so hard to make out. Some of the side objectives can be entertaining, but some of them seem a little buggy where they just don't get marked as complete when you've clearly done so. The ridiculously edgy comments the edge lord character makes were funny at first but I got sick of them by the 3rd level. Lastly, even on easy there is a pretty big difficulty spike on the later levels, I'd say level 4 onwards.\n\nOverall it's decent but nothing special, there's no great variety in anything at all, including weapons and executions, level design and gameplay, but it can be fun if you just want a quick murder session, but you probably won't play it for too long at once. Not worth the price tag I feel.

reviewText:
While Hatred was an...interesting concept when the trailers first came out and seemed like itd provide a gruesomely dark story with great isometric gameplay, the game unfortunately fails to provide. You play as an unnamed man who simply has lost all faith in the world and decides to go out and kill every person in sight in a mass murder simulation (you know, for the kids, right?). What caused him to become like this? Why is it seemingly impossible to kill one man when you have the police, SWAT, and the Army against him? Don't bother asking because you'll never get the answer. There is little to no plot other than you just going around killing people and finding ways to do so. The graphics are not bad for its current update, but it was nearly impossible to play at first due to the developers not taking into consideration the port for different graphics cards. Gameplay is simple: run and gun and survive until you kill everybody. On the side, you gain health by performing distrubing executions on people in agony, which can be very hard to stomach. While it can be enjoyable at first (not the concept itself, but the gameplay), it runs thin by the third level and loses its grasp on your attention due to its repetitive nature which actually keeps players from coming back for more. I will give the game credit for its physics and destruction engine because it was pretty cool to see the buildings crumble from grenades, but its not satisfying enough to keep the player from coming back.

Hatred was an interesting idea when it came out, but between its void story, its rather dull gameplay, and very low replay value, itd be best if you spent $20 elsewhere.

Final Verdict: 3/10

Pros:
-Pretty Good Graphics
-Nice Physics Engine

Cons:
-Little to no plot
-Very unlikable character
-gameplay dully repetitive
-no replay value
-rather disturbing content

reviewText:
Hatred was very contoversial when it first released and for good reason this is a game centered around mass murder if you are offended by this, leave! this game will only serve to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you off. Aside from the premise the game is a twinstick shooter, that feels very much like a arcade game with a few modern features like vaulting over cover and crouching.

All of the weapons feel satisfying to use and the executions are brutal. This game is amazing in the graphics department and is truly something to look at especially if you have a rig good enough to max it out, absolutely gorgeous. The game has a unigue style where it is mostly black and white but certain things like blood,fire,and police lights are fully colored.

This game does have a major flaw however, the AI mainly for civilians, the majority of them do not act like a civilian would in this scenario, some will just stand there with their thumb up their â™¥â™¥â™¥ staring at a wall or hell even run towards you at times it breaks emersion and generally makes the game less fun because you'd think it would be satisfying to kill them (which it it most of the time) but sometimes it isn't because it feels like you are shooting absolute morons who cannot fathom the idea of common sense.

The same goes for the hostile in the game (police,vigilantes,military etc.) but in a different way, i won't lie this one is much harder to notice, but once you figure it out it can easily break the game, the hostiles will not think to check the second floor in a house if your up there! you can make all the noise you want, but usually no one will come up occasionally someone might wander up there but it will usually be one at a time and they are very easy to take out, you can just sit up there and wait for all the hostiles below to funnel upstairs (it takes a very long time) and you can easily take them out, its almost like a onofficial safe zone its broken and it desperately needs a patch.

over all i've enjoyed hatred so far and im sure i will all the way to the end but these are issues that cannot be overlooked when you are deciding whether or not to buy this game

I give it a 7/10 would commit mass murder again

reviewText:
Extremely fun game. For anyone who thinks this game crosses the line, it is no different than what goes on in GTA or similar games.

You are psycopath who thinks everyone deserves to die. Simple as that. Game runs smoothly and the different weapons certainly have their pros and cons. Grenades are satisfying and the side missions are a good addition. Ammo for your favorite weapons is hard to come by (starting rifle) but have found that in the later levels this doesn't become such an issue. SWAT members are a good source of automatic ammo.

The only real con I have to this game is it is hard to keep track of the cursor, even if it is a bright color like yellow or green that is not really seen in game. This may be all on me, but it isn't really that big of a negative, just frustrating at times.

Overall, I would give this an 8/10

reviewText:
Witness a beautiful tale of an Emo and the love he has for his Guns: Burt, Ernie, and Pedro.  He tours the land introducing Burt, Ernie, and Pedro to lots of new and interesting people.

The plot takes an interesting twist though, as people don't seem keen on meeting the Emo and his friends, and they run away from him (hurting the Emo's fragile feelings)!  Then the police turn up and try to make him go away, but the Emo wins them over by giving them lots of free lead.

10/10 Would bring Ernie to the masses again

reviewText:
In Hatred, you play as a man named Nahd Impoortand who didn't get his high five. Now he's realized that he wasn't the only the one who didn't obtain that high five. Now you go on an adventure giving people as many high fives as possible with your happy dagger and smug AK-47. Eventually Nahd doesn't think that's enough so he tries his best to spread his high fives all across the city with a nuclear explosion. Eventually everybody gets their high five and Nahd's work is done. Good job, Nahd.

Recommended for all casual players or just parents who are thinking about the game for their child. Don't be fooled by the adults only rating, it was just an early April Fool's joke that got out of hand later. So buy this game if you've never gotten that high five.

10/10 would high five again.

reviewText:
Video review:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HgrpoLmoEGM

Hatred, a game which evokes hatred and controversy not just in its own gaming world even outside it. The game is predominantly hated by humanists, my little pony fans, unprofessional journalists and minecraft gamers. But this game has laid again the groundwork for that, whereof were games in the past and it is furious shooting at everything, that moves, and that furious shooting which you can chill out with after a hard day. The game became very popular especially thanks to an Adult Only label and execution cinematics in trailers. However, there arenâ€™t much execution cinematics in the game itself currently, and murdering civilians isnâ€™t different from for example Counter Strike or Call of Duty. Otherwise you can turn off execution cinematics in options if it isnâ€™t comfortable for you. The game shouldnâ€™t get the Adult Only label but rather Pure Gamers Only label, because gamers arenâ€™t psychopaths. Psychopaths are completely different people.

Currently the technical side of this game isnâ€™t perfect. There are many glitches, and it happened to me two times that I was respawned outside the map, and I had to kill myself with a grenade â€“ thanks God I had some! Authors of this game apparently donâ€™t know how to use the Unreal Engine 4, in which the game was made, properly because the performance is very badly optimized. Sometimes you will have very low FPS even though you have a very high-end PC. Unfortunately, this is purely developers fault, but I believe that they will work on it, as itâ€™s an interesting indie studio.

The graphic in this game is very acceptable for me personally. I like the monochromatic atmosphere of this game, which totally takes you into the gloomy atmosphere of cold-blooded murders. The psychics in the game works great too and lots of different games should take the example from demolition options in this game. Explosions are absolutely beautiful and in detail processed. I havenâ€™t seen such well made explosions for a long time. The environment or levels, which are overall seven, are beautifully designed, and it worth to explore all, because otherwise you would miss interesting places. There are lots of side quests but no one will takes you to these interesting places. Completing side quests gives you respawn points which is like a checkpoint. You can choose from 3 different difficulties â€“ easy, hard and extreme.

There arenâ€™t many weapons but it correspond more to the reality. Matter of course is handgun, SMG, rifle and even a rocket launcher. There are 3 types of throwing explosive projectiles â€“ a grenade, a Molotov cocktail and a stun grenade. In options you can change the colour and type of the crosshair. Especially well processed is flamethrower. It just phenomenally burns and burning people will entertains you. But itâ€™s a shame that you wonâ€™t enjoy the flamethrower much in this game. You can also drive a police car or a military vehicle but they are too vulnerable and blow up very fast. Itâ€™s a shame that you canâ€™t use common cars in neighborhood.

The games audio perfectly complements the atmosphere and itâ€™s well set in each level. Especially in the Train level and Power Plant level music fits perfectly. The music never sounds annoyingly in the whole game. The main protagonist sometimes while murdering says some harsh yelling, which appears more comically than hatefully. Sounds of weapons including reloading sound very realistic.

Even though authors have already planned lots of improvements, they should start with technical side and supplement the knowledge about the Unreal Engine 4. I have noticed few things that need to be upgraded: throwing explosive projectiles. Itâ€™s too slow and the angle and power of throwing would come in handy. I miss the choice to permanently highlight aggressive units in the option â€“ itâ€™s better for aiming. And I also miss the option to catch civilians and use them as a human shield or eventually a possibility to execute a standing person. By the way executions replenish your life. Amazing would be experience system or levelling profile of your character, which would be suitable for skirmish mode or endless wave mode. Cooperative mode could be about two psychopathic outcasts killing more politicians in other cities, after they had watched news about the murder of Downtowns politician and had been inspired. When you had started the apocalypse, I would also appreciate if other security forces such as rescuers and firemen would arrive. What needs to be improved is AI (artificial intelligence) because civilians can see you through the wall and stealth doesnâ€™t work. Although civilians pick up dead persons weapons, they are able to go right in front of you for the weapon and get killed. Something like fear factor is missing here. Currently is just Top murderers leaderboard but I would appreciate some Time trial leaderboard too. One last thing that I would like to mention is running over by a car â€“ it always instantly kills you compared to for example the grenade. I would be pleased if they would change the damage, which will depend on the angle and power of the hit. I donâ€™t mention things that authors are going to do.

In conclusion I must say that Hatred is a great game, which is unnecessarily hated by family friendly gaming reviewers. And itâ€™s just because they donâ€™t know anything about origin games, and what games used to be. Users rating via Steam gaming platform says it all or it at least gives evidence how reviewers arenâ€™t objective, and they donâ€™t know for example the game Crusader: No Regret, which Hatred reminds me a lot. Hatred on highest difficulty is an interesting and tactical game. Now seriously, which of reviewers had actually finished the whole game on highest difficulty? I do! And I highly recommend this game!

reviewText:
Hatred is a beautiful but incredibly bland title with shallow and repetitive gameplay, lacklustre combat and exteremely dull levels. I found the experience completely mundane and had no choice but to claim a refund under the circumstances. This game is not even worth a third of the asking price.

This controversial title is essentially a twin stick isometric shooter that looks very impressive with a dark and gritty atmosphere. Sadly this is the only postitive aspect of Hatred as everything else is lacking on a significant level. The controls are wonky and the concept of killing everything and everyone becomes tiresome very quickly indeed. The game doesn't really have a shock factor either to warrant the controversy that it's generated - I feel this was more of a publicity stunt to draw attention to the game as opposed to people having legitimate concerns about the premise.

It is also a very challenging title which isn't really a negative but the difficulty can often frustrate due to cumbersome controls and incredibly accurate AI. If you fail a level at any time; you have to go back to the start. You can however regenerate health but this involves performing executions which result in a repetitive cinematic cut scene over and over - sometimes you'd rather go without health just to avoid having to watch yet another same cut scene. You also have the opportunity per level to earn a respawn token by completing a secondary objective but as this often surrounds executions which like the above; you may want to avoid as this aspect just kills the flow of what is already exceptionally mundane gameplay.

Overall; Hatred is a very impressive looking title that lacks any substance whatsoever. The gameplay mechanics are irritating and the lack of depth along with the bland structure leave the product significantly lacking. It'll only take a few hours to finish but you'll be bored long before then. If you are still interested in taking a punt on the game; just don't exceed the two hour criteria for a refund - this game is essentially the same throughout. Everyone else should simply avoid - it's not worth the refund hassle even if you're mildly curious.

reviewText:
The game that Simpsons and the like parodied in the nineties after Mortal Kombat and such came out.

This is the game that all the hysterical parents didn't want their kids to play: a murder simulator, full of blood, gore, and mindless ultra violence, made with the intent of corrupting the young. Except it's not.

It's a goofy, over the top look into the minds of angst ridden kids who write misanthropic poems in their bedrooms, walls plastered with posters of extreme metal bands and drawings of satanic symbols, while hate filled music made by grown men wearing clothes either from a military surplus store or the hot topic.

It's a dumb game, but it's also a very fun game (when it isn't keyboard and mouse throwing out the window frustrating). It's fun because it allows you to do what every single one of us have wanted to do when we get bullied at school, fired from work or when a car drives by, hits a puddle and splashes water all over you ruining your brand new clothes. It's a polygons and pixels shooting other polygons and pixels for the sake of your entertainment, nothing more.

Plus you get to light a mob of people attending a political rally on fire with a flamethrower. Who wouldn't want to do that?

reviewText:
A game about a guy that loses it and starts murdering the world.  If you've read other criticism of this game, then you know how divided the opinions are on it. I suspect the reasons for that are twofold.  First, the controversy surrounding the game's trailer. And second, the subject material. I think it really comes down to this one thing:  are you okay playing as a mass murderer? If you're not, then you have no business being here. Because that's all this game is. There will be no redemption.

If you're still reading, then buy the game and come along for the ride. Because a lot of the negatives leveled at Hatred have been greatly exaggerrated. The main character's dialogue is corny, yes. The driving, should you choose to do it, is a bit awkward. Everything else is pefect.  If you've seen any video of this game, then you know what you're getting into. A black and white art style, puncuated with colorful police lights, explosions, and splashes of red. Gunshots are crisp. So are the screams of terror. The destruction system is top notch. Buildings can be lit on fire, blown apart, shot through. It allows for more tactics then I expected. And you will need those tactics because this game can be very difficult.

A few tips:  play with mouse and keyboard. I tried my Xbox controller and found that it just wasn't accurate or fast enough for the chaos of this game. Also, I suggest going into the menus and changing the color and shape of your aiming reticle. The default size of the reticle, along with the white coloration, tended to get lost in the background during some of the more tense moments. Further, do not expect to go toe-to-toe with the army of opponents Hatred will throw at you. When things get too hectic, retreat, refill your health with a few executions, and ambush opponents when they come to investigate.

Thumbs up for the developers having the guts to make a game like this, and to Steam for selling it.

reviewText:
Someone clearly wasn't hugged enough as a child.
'90s action dialogue? Check.
Slightly better than B-List voice acting? Check.
Killable everything? Check.
Overall, I think this was a fun but short game. I didn't care much for the controls, but the gameplay was fun enough to keep me playing. I think it's a great game to let off some steam but if you think it's going to be cutting edge in any real way you'll be disappointed. The media certainly hyped this game up to be far more controversial than I think it really is; it could also be because the majority of us are so de-sensitized to violence in video games that it doesn't seem as bad as we anticipated it to be. I would have liked to see more variety in the executions and the NPCs, and there is a surprising lack of children in this game which probably would have helped it reach a more controversial level. I honestly don't think too many people will be in shock and awe at this game unless they have never played a violent video game in their lives. All-in-all I do not regret purchasing this game and would recommend it to anyone that likes a good mindless shooter.

DLC I'd like to see:
School/College
Hospital
Subway/Metro
Retirement Home
DMV
Co-op killing spree mode

reviewText:
When I started playing this game, the first thing I noticed was how well animated the player character was. His long hair and black leather coat flow softly as he moves. The maps are equally beautiful with many interesting details (that you can DESTROY!) pop culture jokes and internet memes, some of which you'll only see in the execution mode (corn â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ers!). The victims will talk back at you, and while most of them beg for their life, others will sass you defiantly before you kill them. Your inner monologue is as corny as you can expect and is a helpful reminder not to take the game too seriously.

The game is short - only 7 levels with three difficulties - and took me roughly 10 hours to complete. You could probably rush through it in five hours, if you ignore all the side quests. My only regret is how difficult the Misogynist achievement is: I've killed 7,000 people in total, you'd think that 2,000 of them were women!

Hatred is a rare power fantasy, so have some fun with it. You are not a hero.

reviewText:
Devastated by the Rare Pepe crash of 2015, Anon (his name is not important) does what any /r9k/ hero would do - he cleanses the world of the normies. With a mighty REEEEEEEEE, he guns down every Chad and Chadette in sight, with each kill being worth 1 good boy point. In the end, he may not be able to sell his Rare Pepe collection, but at least he has a lifetime supply of tendies.

Pros
+ Brilliant destruction
+ Upset countless SJWs
+ You can use a good variety of weapons
+ It has an open level design
+ There is mod support planned

Cons
- Needs a lot more more optimisation
- Respawn points aren't a good design choice
- Level 6 will probably make you want to put down the game and go on a rampage irl.

Conclusion: First letter of every line under pros.


It's a good game. Not the best game ever created, but a solid and fun title. The story isn't exactly brilliant, but it's a means to an end. If you enjoy going on mass murder sprees in games (or you enjoy it irl and are playing this from prison) then you may very well enjoy this too.

reviewText:
The game that Simpsons and the like parodied in the nineties after Mortal Kombat and such came out.

This is the game that all the hysterical parents didn't want their kids to play: a murder simulator, full of blood, gore, and mindless ultra violence, made with the intent of corrupting the young. Except it's not.

It's a goofy, over the top look into the minds of angst ridden kids who write misanthropic poems in their bedrooms, walls plastered with posters of extreme metal bands and drawings of satanic symbols, while hate filled music made by grown men wearing clothes either from a military surplus store or the hot topic.

It's a dumb game, but it's also a very fun game (when it isn't keyboard and mouse throwing out the window frustrating). It's fun because it allows you to do what every single one of us have wanted to do when we get bullied at school, fired from work or when a car drives by, hits a puddle and splashes water all over you ruining your brand new clothes. It's a polygons and pixels shooting other polygons and pixels for the sake of your entertainment, nothing more.

Plus you get to light a mob of people attending a political rally on fire with a flamethrower. Who wouldn't want to do that?

Hatred is a top down shooter really similar to Postal (1997)

There isnâ€™t really a story to Hatred, itâ€™s just you play as this guy who hates humanity and decides to go on a killing spree. The game tries to be serious, grim, dark and edgy but it just falls flat on its face because it isnâ€™t violent enough or dark and grim enough and the lines the character says is really tone ruining they are kind of cheesy but for the most part they are quite cringe worthy. Though this game failing to be serious and edgy and dark isnâ€™t really a bad thing.

The gameplay is really similar to postal where you go place to place and you have to kill a certain amount of people before progressing to the next level, though there are a few point A to B missions here and there but itâ€™s mostly kill x amount of people. There are also side objectives which will reward you with respawn tokens, you can also drive vehicles but for the most part nearly all of them will be destroyed way too easily, you have a health and armour system and you gain health back by executing people, you have a three weapon limit, and this game has a very detailed destruction system with the environments, houses and buildings.

The controls are difficult to begin with but after a short while youâ€™ll get the hang of it, you might run into a few health issues where there are no defenceless people running around and thereâ€™s a group of armed people nearby and youâ€™re low on health and there is a few weird examples of weapon balancing since a 9mm pistol does more damage than an ak47 does, but this game is just fun to cause destruction and chaos.

The controversy:

If you donâ€™t know there has been A LOT of controversy surrounding this game because of its content in killing innocent people and in America this game got the AO rating but it is all underserved, this is nothing new, itâ€™s nothing you havenâ€™t seen before from previous violent video games such as manhunt, postal, grand theft auto, soldier of fortune etc. so stop complaining and crying YOU BUNCH OF â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ING â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥!

reviewText:
Fun little isometric arcade game. At times it can be a bit repetitive, but that's a problem most isometric shooters have. This is the type of game you play for about 20-30 mins to blow off some steam and fill up your time with. Lots of people have reported having graphical problems, but I've had no such issues, the game runs solid for me. Pretty much everyone that has said issues has AMD hardware, so that kind of explains it ;P

The only big thing that's really affecting my enjoyment of the game is the health and respawn system. I get the idea behind executions healing the player, it's honestly a pretty good idea that fits with the game's theme, but come on, have some medpacks lying around too, or have the player's health regenerate halfway. It's hard as hell getting people to become wounded.

Also, PPPLLLLEEEAAAASSSSEEEE get rid of the current respawn system. I get that the game doesn't want people to save scum, but having to earn respawn tokens lest start the huge â™¥â™¥â™¥ level from the beginning is annoying as â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. Have the player's progress after getting to a respawn point undone, but have the amount of respawns at said point unlimited, that would be much better. Or at the very least, give the player some respawn tokens on the fly.

Still, it's a fun game. If you like the Alien Shooter series and have a taste for dark exploitation films, you might like this. It's really not the threat to gaming and society as a whole that it was made out to be, it's just good ol' arcade action delivered from a different perspective. Really didn't deserve the AO rating.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YoPshsUjiUI&index=1&list=PLTj9drPC92M2iXZVy0bCpf02SUE8zLaKG

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

Hatred is a top down(ish) 3rd person shoot 'em up action, dark-themed psychotic game. I was pleasantly surprised by the variety of options available. The graphics of the game are dark, where the shadows and textures propel a dark atmosphere and tone. The music and voice effects really help set this tone, making the player feel uncomfortable or ill at ease. The voice effects of people
screaming also add to this dark, unsettling feel. The difficulty settings are well done, where harder difficulties will present a challenge.

The story is pretty much nonexistent. Your character feels that society has failed him, and decided to go on a killing rampage to the death. It doesn't hold back; there is no comedy or satire, only pure bloodshed. Because there is no build up or lead in as to why the character became this way, it is hard to immerse yourself in the story,
or relate to his decisions. There is no pulling back for him, just pure anger. The players not  able to stop what is happening, which  may give some a feeling of distaste or horror. Many of the people being killed have no way to defend themselves. As the game progresses,
you start to battle soldiers, and it begins to feel less about doing evil acts, and more about fighting threatening opponents.

The weapons each carry weight, which is nice to see. Adding an option to upgrade weapons would have been a nice addition, as it would have provided a connection from the player to the character, such as having quicker reload times, for example. The enemies will in time shoot you from off screen, and they will start to attack in a horde, which can be overwhelming, as it is supposed to be, but there is no real way to thin them out with ease. Because you get overwhelmed so fast, there is no option to fall back to a fortified location, and no mines or traps you are able to place. This can be good if your looking for something harder in this genre other wise it will be more of a annoyance.

The level design is beautiful. It's expansive enough, with plenty of places to take cover, and the areas feel like what they are supposed to. A neighborhood feels like a neighborhood. I never felt lost, and the directives plus the minimap were fairly straight forward. Walls, cars, buildings, provide variety in escape access, or availability to create your own path, which I appreciate. Its always nice to blow your own door into a wall.

The only way to replenish resources such as health is to perform an execute move, more often successful on civilians than soldiers. If you hold off on killing civilians, you can save them for when you need extra health. They become more valuable as a resource or medkit, rather than just a stain on the wall as they are at the beginning of the game.

What this game nails is the overall tone of painful, almost unbearable discomfort that comes from perhaps feeling of 'this could happen in this society; that could be me'. The last thing you would want to do would be a civilian with this character coming down the road at you. Seeing the evil he depicts, the actions that he takes, causes the player to really think that this sort of thing really exists in the world.

Performance wise, and content wise, this game is great. If you like top down shooters, absolutely this game is for you. The weapons feel heavy and good; there are a few weapons and movement issues- not gamebreaking but sometimes inconvenient which I go  more into during the video. The story and the theme is dark; it's in your face, loud, and extreme, and has been flushed out perfectly to do such. This is one of the best top down shooters I have played. The theme may be hard for some to get past, but I found it very worthwhile in gameplay.

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

reviewText: This game is quite crazy but fun at the same time.. playing as a villian helbent on causing a complete 1 man apocalypse. This game kind of reminded me of those evil moments in Fallout or GTA where you just play ruthless and evil through the game. It's oddly funny how crazy the guy is and some of the things he says are ridculous and off the wall. All in all I'm not really much for top down shooters, aside from X-Com or the oringinal Fallout games, but it caught me by surprise how well the gameplay was easy to figure out and the engine made a nice spice to the destruction and mayhem you could cause unlike you could in GTA games. Blowing up buildings, being able to shoot through walls, and burn places down with a single molotov felt so awesome, along with the classic chain reaction of cars blowing up one after the next. This game felt unique compared to a lot of other top down shooters, while it's quite controversial to many I would argue it can be just as crazy as GTA or Fallout with the ruthless evil-crazed goal of wiping out everything. But in my opnion.. I'd give this rating a 9/10 a 9 because I feel like the story felt slightly short even on a high difficulty. But it was well worth every buck. I'd say this game has great potential in forming into a small franchise or even some twisted undead sequal added in the mix. Not giving away any spoilers, but the developers or people who beat the game may get the idea. Loved this game, and I hope to see another or added content to this one. Great job on the game guys!

reviewText: This game is quite crazy but fun at the same time.. playing as a villian helbent on causing a complete 1 man apocalypse. This game kind of reminded me of those evil moments in Fallout or GTA where you just play ruthless and evil through the game. It's oddly funny how crazy the guy is and some of the things he says are ridculous and off the wall. All in all I'm not really much for top down shooters, aside from X-Com or the oringinal Fallout games, but it caught me by surprise how well the gameplay was easy to figure out and the engine made a nice spice to the destruction and mayhem you could cause unlike you could in GTA games. Blowing up buildings, being able to shoot through walls, and burn places down with a single molotov felt so awesome, along with the classic chain reaction of cars blowing up one after the next. This game felt unique compared to a lot of other top down shooters, while it's quite controversial to many I would argue it can be just as crazy as GTA or Fallout with the ruthless evil-crazed goal of wiping out everything. But in my opnion.. I'd give this rating a 9/10 a 9 because I feel like the story felt slightly short even on a high difficulty. But it was well worth every buck. I'd say this game has great potential in forming into a small franchise or even some twisted undead sequal added in the mix. Not giving away any spoilers, but the developers or people who beat the game may get the idea. Loved this game, and I hope to see another or added content to this one. Great job on the game guys!

reviewText: Ok, let me first stat off by saying that this game DOES NOT have a long story mode at all. reviewText:
Well what do I say? The game plays exactly as expected. Typical top-down shooter style of game play. The game will definitely not be for people who like a lot of depth and expect something new and completely ground-breaking, but for people who simply like hours of mindless fun, I would definitely recommend. I personally think the game is a pretty fun game, as it is nothing different than Postal 1, which I really like. I am not going to sit here and say it is a masterpiece, because it isn't. I do not care about the context of the killing as I do not care about mindless AI within a game. If I did, I would be crying every time I senselessly run over a pedestrian in GTA.

This game is not without its flaws though. The AI are kinda eh-ish, as they will run directly at you while clearly knowing you are the guy that is friggin murdering everyone. If the devs could fix that, that would be great. The game also gets rather repetetive, but it is not meant to be any different than that. It is a game about a misanthrope who goes on a rampage, that is it. If you see the trailers, hear what the game is about, and still buy and whine about it being repetetive, that is on you.

In conclusion, I got exactly what was advertised. If you are sensitive to non-existent people dying, than stay away from this game. If you liked Postal 1, you will like this game. If you like mindless deadly action, you will like this game. I give the game a good 3.5 out of 5. Cheers.

You play as some metal as f**k dude feeling disgusted as what society has become and channels his rage in a positive manner for the good of the community! This valiant hero takes it upon himself to purge society of its sin and debauchery with the best way to solve all of life's problems: violence!

reviewText:
People seem to be comparing this Â£15.00 (or equivalent) game to a Triple-A title. Fifteen pounds, that's the equivalent of a meal in a restaurant - hell.. less than a meal. You can't compare this to GTA, you can't compare this to Battlefield, you can't compare this to Witcher. Why would you? Big-budget organizations vs. a small Polish games company with a considerably lesser budget and experience.

The game isn't perfect, the A.I. is buggy at times, the performance isn't superb, and aiming with a controller is ridiculously difficult. That being said, you have to appreciate the game for what it DOES do right (and it does a 'lot' of things right).

The art style is superb, I'm sure I'm not the first to compare it to something like Sin City, but I'm going to anyway. The game is predominantly black-and-white, with certain items and effects being in colour. Sirens flash blue and red, explosions are shades of orange and yellow, and blood is purple. No, I'm just kidding, it's red. Very red. The destruction system is superb. You can shatter glass windows, blow holes through walls, drive vehicles THROUGH buildings, it's phenomenal. The whole feel of the game is incredibly sinister. Sure, you can do these things on GTA, but it's not stylized to be a rampage 'sim', if you will. Hatred on the other hand, represents indiscriminate murder for the sake of it. The screams of innocent people as you slit their throat, set them on fire, shoot them through the head, all sounds so real.

People also argue the game was made to be 'edgy'. I hate that word. The developers set out to make a game of their choosing, and they did so successfully. They didn't need to advertise the game, because the media sh*tstorm that occurred as a result of such a game did it for them. People criticize that, whereas I praise it. It might seem like a simple premise, so why did nobody do it sooner? Destructive Creations had the balls to do it, and it paid off.

I wouldn't say the game has huge replay value. That being said, it's not pretending to be something it's not. If you're willing to sacrifice a meager sum of money for a few hours fun here and there, I'd highly recommend it.

8/10.

reviewText:
All things considered a pretty fun game but not anything revolutionary.
Shooting feels good and the destruction and physics system are really cool. It's really fun to just blow stuff up.

The game gets ridiculously hard after a while even on easy though - I can't imagine what playing on the hardest difficulty is like. You will spend more time fighting cops than murdering civilians for the most part.

The protagonist is pretty funny as he says the cheesiest, edgiest stuff you can imagine. He really is Linkin Park tier edgy.

Graphically the game looks good but at the moment I'm writing this review there are some performance issues and the game seems to run pretty bad even on high end PCs. Hopefully the developers will fix this through patches.

I would recommend it, but you might want to wait until a sale as there is probably not a whole lot of replay value to it once you have finished it.

reviewText:
If Postal 1 was to come out today, it would be like Hatred.

An isometric run and gun game featuring fun gunplay, an astonising damage model/physics system, beautiful visuals and some great animations ranging from simple movement to close up executions. It's gory, brutal with lots of one-liners and above all fun to play. The npc's have great voice actors that help with the immersion. The developers also recently added new side quests and a new Survival mode!

The game doesn't take itself very seriously and I regard it as such. The story is as simple as a guy going on a rampage trying to kill as many people as possible, along with a couple of sidequests that usually involve even more killing. Nothing more, nothing less. It can be very challenging on the highest difficulty setting, found myself cornered by law enforcement one too many times. Challenge is good!

They've also fixed most of the performance issues in the latest update and added even more visual settings. I believe the game is definitely worth a try.

7/8

reviewText:
http://youtu.be/6-VHtdSYb1I
Game: Hatred
Genre: Isometric shooter
Developer: Destructive Creations
Publisher: Destructive Creations
Copy bought for review

Hatred is an isometric shooter developed and published by Destructive Creations, and has become famous due to the violent nature of the game.

STORYThe story isn't deep and neither serious, paying homage to multiple exploitation movies of the 80s. You play as the Antagonist, a man who hates humanity and decides to commit mass murder until he dies. The dialogue is mostly said by the Antagonist, and is either painfully dumb or hilariously cheesy. This game is not meant to be taken seriously.

GRAPHICSUsing the Unreal Engine 4, the game looks good and has great destruction. Unfortunately, the performance is very poor, the environments look bland due to the black-and-white style and the NPCs are not much varied.

GAMEPLAYYou go around and shoot people. The end.
All joking aside, your goal is to go to points of interest and kill everyone that you find in the surprisingly huge levels. You can use three weapons at a time (ranging from pistols to flamethrowers) and three types of grenade as well as gasoline tanks and whatnot scattered around the environment. You can also drive some vehicles, but they usually destroy after a few shots. If a person falls to the ground and doesn't die, you can execute him/her in order to regain health. The animations tend to get repetitive and annoying, but you can disable them in the options. The A.I. isn't even all that smart, with civilians casually strolling by while you are stomping someone's head on the ground.
The concept is repetitive, and if what you have read might keep you entertained, than buy this game. Otherwise it's not for you.

CHALLENGEThe game is challenging thanks to the high number of police officers. You will mostly likely die because of explosions, getting run over by a car or simply not executing someone. The order difficulties tend to make the make more entertaining, while still not being too frustrating and impossible.

SOUNDMost of the sound effects are fine, but the music isn't all that memorable. The voice acting is cheesy and the music lends itself to the nature of the game, with a hard-rock soundtrack that fits the gameplay but isn't all that great outside of it.

REPLAYABILITYA total of 7 levels, 42 achievements, mod support and possible DLC make this a game playable once or twice in its current state. There are some secrets in the areas that you explore, but nothing worthile.

Much ado about nothing. This game will be forgotten in a few months and we will all look back and laugh at how everyone overreacted. The game is a good time-waster, not that different from something like 1997's Postal or going on a mindless rampage in GTA. If you like the genre, you'll have a blast playing this.

reviewText:
The spiritual successor to the original Postal.

Take the role of The Antagonist (or alternatively refered to as 'Not Important', or 'Notim Portant'), and embark on a quest to kill as many as you can before you die on seven large (HUGE) long levels, complemented by a beautiful dark ambient soundtrack while you blow holes in building walls, execute people to regain health (or simply for pleasure). Take advantage of a large arsenal of hand held weapons, and mounted machine guns to aid you in your quest.

On top of that, you can also take control of three followers of the Antagonist, each with their own strenghts and weaknesses in the glorious Survival Mode. The more you play, the more weapons and perks you unlock. Fight wave after wave of enemies consisting of regular policemen, SWAT officers and Army Soldiers armed to the teeth, getting harder with each passing wave, with the occasional mini-boss enemy on three different maps.

The highlight of Survival Mode?

BRUTAL DEATH METAL SOUNDTRACK BY BLOOD RED THRONE!

So if you're a fan of the Postal series, and a Metalhead, you will LOVE THIS GAME! Easily one of the best video game soundtracks of all time.

Also, there's a Workshop if you're interested in some batshit crazy mods, and Linux support.

Oh, and anyone who says Postal Redux is better than Hatred is biased and full of crap.

reviewText:
I'm not going to pull any punches here, this game is garbage.

It tries to recreate the mechanics of old-school Postal but has none of the wit that Running with Scissors used in their game and just becomes tired and dull very quickly. I played it for less than an hour and that's all I could stand.

Clearly the developers tried to sell this one on the back of controversy and to some extent that worked but there are so many games on Steam right now that are far more worthy of your time and money than this one. If you find this game in your queue then my advice is just to click next and move on.

reviewText:
Well... Hatred is here, and it sucks.

Okay, first of all, I don't have a particular problem with the game's theme itself. Unfortunately, our society isn't perfect and yes, there are tragic occurrences when some bolk goes mad and kills a lot of people out of God knows what. It happens. And as such, a game in fact has every right to touch such a sad subject. It's not even a new thing, just check on Postal for instance!

But man, Destructive Creations screwed up everything they could do right in this case. The engine itself was a bad idea, UE4 is poorly optimized and unnecessary for a top-down-view shooter, Unity would have been a far better choice. The game is sluggish, runs horribly on the same PC that makes GTA V fly, and ugly as hell too. So there's that.

In the terms of gameplay, it shows nothing new, and gets boring after a few minutes. Is it cool to kill people without a reason? Well maybe it could be, but isn't, thanks for the horrible AI that makes them feel like mindless idiots wandering like zombies. It's just bad.

Just like the shooting mechanic: aiming is difficult, there is no cover system, the enemy is always overpowered, and it's just simply not fun to shoot. Which is sad because in such a game, using guns might be a selling point.

And the game ends in 4 hours, giving us absolutely no reason to play it again. Sorry DC, this isn't the crusade we wish to see.

reviewText:
Hatred leaves me with mixed feelings. I have not completed the game, but I plan on it, but this review will be based on my early impressions after playing for a few hours.

The gameplay is your standard twin stick shooter with an interesting twist. Instead of being the protagonist and fighting off zombies, monsters, robots etc, you are the evil antagonist, senselessly slaughtering innocents and police alike. There is very little plot, aside from you hate everyone, and want everyone to die. The Controls are a little clunky if you don't have a controller set up. I've died once or twice because the controls are just silly.

Pro's:
Beautiful graphics for a twin stick shooter, among the best I've seen to date for this genre.
Brutal Executions (only way to heal yourself)
Destructible Environments (Who doesn't love blowing a hole through a building and killing everyone who is on the inside?)
Variety of weaponry: Run out of bullets? pick up a cops gun and use that instead.
Side missions to spice things up a bit and add a layer of difficulty.
Civilians will pick up weapons and fight back: Again, adding another layer of difficulty. They fight for their lives instead of just being lambs for the slaughter.
Explosions! Lots of Red" gas cans
recommended:
and other combustibles that you can shoot to make a big explosion. Excellent if there are a few cops near it!

Con's:
Keyboard controls are clunky. Difficult to move and throw grenades / kick / aim while moving and shooting.
Grayscale makes it hard to differentiate between civilians and police officers / swat team members
No real Plot: I feel my self wanting there to be a reason why I hate everyone so much that they all need to die.
Repetitive game play. There is no real diversity
hoursPlayed: as in every other twin stick shooter I've played

7/10

reviewText:
After spending a few hours with this game I'm ready to tell you what I think.

I have absolute no problem with the content of the game, I do the same in GTA 4/5 when I'm bored. It's a game, it's adult only, get over it.

The game is not that good though... I had fun for the first hour, after that it was just to kill some time. The controls are weird and a lot of times you can't even see who's shooting at you. I also have the problem of sometimes loosing the sight in all confusion and trying to shoot everyone everywhere. There is no reason to do what you're doing, there is no real quests or anything that matters just kill 20 people here, blow this up and kill 10 more people.. It's fun for a short time but it get old quick.

It's not the worst game out there, but its not worth it's price at all. This will be a game you buy to kill some time before work or something like that, do not expect to be knee deep in a dark and interesting story. If this game was on my phone, this is the game I would play when I'm taking a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

So if you are thinking about buying the game, it wont be the worst game you ever buy, but knowing what I know now, I would wait for it to be on sale..

reviewText:
animations are beautifull, the effect of a bullet passing trough someone is something i've never seen in a game before, the physics are astunishing... but.. this game is nothing but an artistic arcade game..

all you ever do, is shoot people till you die.. the only objectives you get is to clear out public places then proceed to the next level.. this is just a postal HD with alot of graphical updates.

the animation is pretty decent during execution.. but when you shoot people just to kill and stop once you think they're dead, they keep flailing like its a rave party with dubstep.. the devs had too  much tought of wasting ammo on people(shooting them even after they're on dead on they'r knees)

i play'd it with a controller to make it easy on me, but the controll on the controller was not optimized at all, multiple times i had trouble shooting people cause i would miss them over and over and over. so it is highly recommended to play with the keyboard as i manage to complete a level with that.
but despite the keyboard or controller, you will easly get stuck on object inside houses..

there isnt really too much about this game other than that. kill alot of people, get an objective to kill more people, then proceed to the next level. its boring after a while, and its the purpose of fun from this game is either to compete with your friends or to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ off your parents for playing this game against they'r will. really.. remember those cartoons where kids were hyped about a super uldtra mega gory killing game? this is that game from that cartoon. except 1 little thing...

the gory stuff you saw from the trailer.. it was mostly executions, right? turns out, when you're playing this game, you dont care. unless you're easly entertained on the same level cats are for yarn from a human perspective, you'll only execute people to replenish your health.

the camera is obnoxious alot of times as it doesnt move fast enough for you to take aim in the oposit direction from where you're aiming, you can extend this view, but that will most of the time, throw you off your sence of direction unless you do it for a splitt secound.

i told myself i wouldnt get it, cause i had some doubts about it, but in the end, i wanted to judge the game fairly so i had to play it. and i'll say, that all the things about this game being banned and hated and all that.. just PR.. its stupid. sure, when you see a mass execution with a closed mind, you're surely be offended, but this is just another game.. you can blast people's head off in most games, even as they plead for they'r life, but you dont really care, because you're just playing a game.

so all in all.. if you look at this with an open mind, its an artistic arcade game with no other purpose to show you how graphics are done, this is just another sandbox game.. as with Gmod, you'll play it for a sertan amount of time, then you'll get bored and might go back every now and then.

reviewText:
Hatred is by no means the best game ever made nor the most violent but there is some enjoyment to be had here.  It reminds me ALOT of the original postal gameplay wise...in fact it is postal gameplay wise.  Its a twin stick shooter at the most basic level.

Visually the game is alright.  It by no means looks bad and it has a style that probably enhances the visuals with its crushed colors.  Its a game you should be able to run at 60fps without any issue.

I had bought this game merely out of spite for all the negative press it has been getting from people who had never played it.  Demonizing and calling for censorship...of a game,  I wasnt expecting much from it but from what Ive played so far im enjoying it.  Classic gameplay without question but its hard enough to keep you coming back and trying to keep pushing further into the levels.

Worth $20?  Hard to say really.  If you like twin stick shooters it might be.  The game has good production quality and its not sloppy but if you dont like the genre it wont change your mind.  If you are a casual fan then wait for a sale.  Its a good value at $15 but paying full price is as close to showing the modern gaming press that you disaprove of their antics as you will ever get.

reviewText:
A solid enough twin stick shooter. Make sure your rig is somewhat beefy before heading in, the game has an intense destruction system/mechanics that can really take the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ out of a lesser PC.

The game plays fairly well and the controls are decent enough. The camera pans where you aim, and can be manipulated about as we'll as you'd expect with the isometric view. Weapons, lines, and animations are all at least passable, and have a nice amount of variety. You'll usually be able to kill a few dozen people before noticing repeats. The lines are lovably cheesy, and the whole game has a very Postal 1 atmosphere while still managing to take itself seriously to a humorous extent.

The destruction mechanics are interesting and fun to use, from driving a car through the front of a grocery store to using grenades to flush out soldiers by blowing down a wall it's but functional and fashionable. Vehicles can be driven and are like miniature race cars with paper-thin exteriors. They're fast, get you where you want to go, but don't expect to live long in it. The player is very mobile and can vault over objects, take cover, sprint, etc in an easily controllable and responsive manner, though it may take some getting used to in order not to get stuck on bushes and leap over cover.

The major flaws are the aforementioned hardware requirements, the isometric view being a pain sometimes (though adapting and using the minimap is a key skill in overcoming this), and the washed out colors making it difficult to see some enemies/locations (but once again there are in-game mechanics in place to nullify this, it's mostly a passive issue that simply requires some more attention to minimaps or using the highlighting key).

All in all if you enjoy a bloody, destructive romp, twin stick shooters, or edgy funtimes that make the politically correct â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ their pants in sheer frothing rage, then this is your kind of game.

P.S.: â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing military base. â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ it.

reviewText:
To be honest, there is nothing about this game that pushes the envelope. The level of violence within has been seen before, and even done a bit better. Character controls feel clunky and inaccurate. The missions are repetitive and the action very quickly grows stale. Executions add a bit of shock value, but only if you've never played any of the Mortal Kombat series. In fact, they're rather abbreviated and goreless. Some blood is spilled, but there is very little in the way of actual gore.

The shock factor simply isn't there. The main character says little mean quips while you fire on civilians, but let's stop kidding ourselves; If we applied a grey filter to Grand Theft Auto and threw in a little extra voice acting, we'd have a better game. The main character isn't even capable of firing from high ground to hit low targets.

I honestly feel as though this game is a poorly executed, level driven Grand Theft Auto clone with a bad camera angle and control scheme. Furthermore, I'd say the vast majority of these positive Steam reviews stem directly from the hype that was applied during the advertising period prior to the game's release.

This could have been a newgrounds flash game, and it would have played no differently.

reviewText:
As its core, Hatred is an interesting game because it reminds us how narrow, formulaic and claustrophobic gaming narratives can be. Imagine cinema without Scarface, Hannibal Lecter or even Mike Leigh's Johnny. Moral ambiguity is essential to the silver screen but remains only a distant hope on our monitors.

The game certainly has its limitations. The core mechanics are those of a middling-quality isometric shooter with some fine destruction physics. Moreover, no significant narrative is provided for the orgy of destruction. This could either be viewed as serving the nihilistic atmosphere, or be considered as a narrative failing when compared to cinematic anti-heroes.

However, considering that the utterances of Hatred's anti-hero are not especially inspired, it's perhaps for the better than the minimalistic approach has been taken - we are free to each craft our own reasons for the violence.

Positives:

- Good atmosphere; cold, grim visuals
- Surprisingly good physics & destruction via UE4. It works well when backed into an Apple Store's bathroom and gunning down soldiers, who finally bring the entire structure down, forcing a hasty run-and-gun exit through the rubble.
- Good concept
- One of the best flamethrowers since Return To Castle Wolfenstein.

Negatives:

- For a game so rooted in gunplay, the actual gun sounds lack punch.
- Something of a manufactured controversy - not really as violent or drastic as people might expect,
- A fundamentally simple game that would struggle to justify a higher price point.
