reviewText:
Short Review to Hatred at it's current state. Releasedate. 6/1/15

Game is unfortunately downright unplayable right now.
Multiple crashes to desktop during the first two missions. (especially during executions.)
Laggy, extremely low fps - but only during critical health state... strange bug... please fix that asap.

another thing: controls.
Way too inaccurate and delayed controls for a quick twin-stick shooter (only tried it with controller so far)

For controllers, there's no real binding-options, whatsoever.
There's one button for weapon change/execution. No binding-possibilities here.
That sucks. Especially when you're desperate for health.
Because the only way to get additional health is by executing someone.
This means: In situations of desperation, caused by low health, a laggy gameplay, and  inaccurate controls, you'll find yourself spamming the 'Y' button in front of each corpse, hoping for some health.
Instead, you'll just switch between weapons most of the time. That's annoying. I'd recommend changing the command for switching weapons to 'holding Y button'.

Question for the devs: Don't you test your games before release?!
Those are bugs and gameplay-flaws that occured to me only after the first hour of gameplay... what the hell??

After spending a few hours with this game I'm ready to tell you what I think.

I have absolute no problem with the content of the game, I do the same in GTA 4/5 when I'm bored. It's a game, it's adult only, get over it.

The game is not that good though... I had fun for the first hour, after that it was just to kill some time. The controls are weird and a lot of times you can't even see who's shooting at you. I also have the problem of sometimes loosing the sight in all confusion and trying to shoot everyone everywhere. There is no reason to do what you're doing, there is no real quests or anything that matters just kill 20 people here, blow this up and kill 10 more people.. It's fun for a short time but it get old quick.

It's not the worst game out there, but its not worth it's price at all. This will be a game you buy to kill some time before work or something like that, do not expect to be knee deep in a dark and interesting story. If this game was on my phone, this is the game I would play when I'm taking a â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥.

So if you are thinking about buying the game, it wont be the worst game you ever buy, but knowing what I know now, I would wait for it to be on sale..

reviewText:
I'm not gonna bother too much talking about the controversial â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥. I'll say that mowing down civilians in it makes me feel kind of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ and uneasy but really going any more in to that is just beating a dead horse that most media outlets can't seem to get enough of. That said, at its core it's a pretty fun twin stick shooter. When it's time to deal with some actual threats the game's actually pretty challenging and rewarding. Ducking, dodging, and generally evading gunfire is pretty intense and the guns themselves feel like they have a proper oomph behind them.

The destructable environments lend a lot to that effect as well when desks, glass, thin walls, and just about anything in the level really is destroyed and blown up by gunfire and  explosions. The destructable environments themselves also allow for some creative approaches to combat as well. SWAT team swarming the house you're holed up in and you need a quick way out? Shoot the conveniently placed oxygen canister in the garage to blow a hole in the side of the building to flee through. Need to clear out a heavily fortified building but can't get through the front door without getting mowed down? Steal a SWAT van and drive it through the side of the building.

That said, it's not without its faults. The driving mechanics feel extremely clunky and sometimes it's easy to glitch the vehicles out on the geometry in really weird ways. I mentioned before that just about anything in the level can be destroyed. Well the game can be pretty stupid at times about what qualifies as just about anything. It's pretty silly when you can ram an armored van straight through the side of a solid concrete building but at the same time it just stops dead in its tracks when it hits a chest high brick wall. The monochrome color scheme can be a pain in the â™¥â™¥â™¥ at times as well. A good example would be the sewer level where it makes it extremely difficult to tell whats blocking your path and what isn't, which makes it fairly easy to get caught on the terrain during a firefight or duck behind what you might think is a pipe running along the floor only to realize after taking two shells in the chest is actually an overhanging pipe.

Overall though, while the premise behind the game might be understandably off putting to people the core mechanics themselves are pretty great. If nothing else, it'd be pretty cool to see what the developers could do with it outside of a mass murder simulator.

reviewText:
Unlike the rest of society I refuse to take the moral high ground here. Hatredâ€™s presence in the collective gaming press has been rife with petty sensationalism,  one could say the reactionaries turn my stomach and have permanently affected how I perceive many more established figures within said community.



On Hatred, one essentially takes on the role of a brooding dread-lord who sadistically murders people as a part of his genocide crusade. Framed in a gorgeous black and white cinematic scheme with tasteful chromatic effects entirely suited for the grisly journey one will undertake.



We have all had bad days, however if one dwells upon committing such acts for a considerable fraction of your existence, Hatred is the perfect game for you,  treat it as a culling holiday.



For this reason I am glad this game exists,  albeit cold,  stark and sociopathic,  ugly true enough. In itâ€™s purest form effectively cathartic.



~Visceral execution sequences~ Endlessly enjoyable destruction of the game environment,  much like a sword this cuts both ways,  both for and against the player.



Presentation aside the game runs reasonably well save texture oddities and physics bugs, persistent clipping is a tad annoying as well however not something I feel detracts from the game-play on a whole.


**Note how the game runs is relative to specs,  only very recently did DC add an advanced graphics options for tweaking on lower end systems,  as of my initial review I was running Hatred with an Nvidia GTX 780ti my second machine couldn't even play Hatred till the very recent optimization patch,  even so there is a drastic difference in performance.(The Marina Sewers and Powerplant levels really take an excessive toll on my AMD Radeon 7570 HD)**



I do feel some decals(blood splatters on npcs) could have been executed better in terms of both visual fidelity and frequency,  particles however are to die for,  great job!



Some feel that the control scheme is atrocious,  I do not have any issue with the default mouse and keyboard controls,  this is probably due to being conditioned to worse control schemes over a decade i.e. the first two Gothic games and Secondlife. While there can be some line of sight issues at given moment nothing stands out as a red flag.



**if one experiences any excessive clunkiness it is probably hardware related - tweak your settings or upgrade your rig.**



As of this review I am at the Military Base, the second to last mission. Based upon my overall experience playing on Hard Difficulty I give Hatred a solid 4 out of Five stars.



**I have progressed further since that point however decided to replay prior maps to unlock certain Steam achievements,  up until mobo failure on my main rig at least. Only very recently have I been able to play Hatred again as the DC team has released a patch which optimizes performance for ATI/AMD hardware to an extent.**


**Don't say Destructive Creations never did anything for their consumers!**



A brief reprieve worth remembering,  kudos to Destructive Creations.



**Lastly,  do not let my review be a standard to how one should feel on this game,  if you hate this game so be it,  however if one feels I am supposed to apologize for enjoying Hatred - â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ you. Gotta love double standards.**

reviewText:
Hatred leaves me with mixed feelings. I have not completed the game, but I plan on it, but this review will be based on my early impressions after playing for a few hours.

The gameplay is your standard twin stick shooter with an interesting twist. Instead of being the protagonist and fighting off zombies, monsters, robots etc, you are the evil antagonist, senselessly slaughtering innocents and police alike. There is very little plot, aside from you hate everyone, and want everyone to die. The Controls are a little clunky if you don't have a controller set up. I've died once or twice because the controls are just silly.

Pro's:
Beautiful graphics for a twin stick shooter, among the best I've seen to date for this genre.
Brutal Executions (only way to heal yourself)
Destructible Environments (Who doesn't love blowing a hole through a building and killing everyone who is on the inside?)
Variety of weaponry: Run out of bullets? pick up a cops gun and use that instead.
Side missions to spice things up a bit and add a layer of difficulty.
Civilians will pick up weapons and fight back: Again, adding another layer of difficulty. They fight for their lives instead of just being lambs for the slaughter.
Explosions! Lots of Red" gas cans
recommended:
and other combustibles that you can shoot to make a big explosion. Excellent if there are a few cops near it!

Con's:
Keyboard controls are clunky. Difficult to move and throw grenades / kick / aim while moving and shooting.
Grayscale makes it hard to differentiate between civilians and police officers / swat team members
No real Plot: I feel my self wanting there to be a reason why I hate everyone so much that they all need to die.
Repetitive game play. There is no real diversity

Physics effects become taxing on your system as a level progresses, as all the destroyed objects don't fade away. (edit: heard from friends with less powerful systems that the physics effects are taxing as all hell on lower powered PCs right from the get-go)

Gameplay is damn good, though what feels like a massive difficulty spike on the last level where you really have to play it smart instead of just killing everyone en masse and rushing the cops head-on, and it really encourages you to get those additional objectives complete (you'll need those respawn points)

Graphically, it's fairly sound and with the exception of the occasional glitch where a decal texture on the floor spreads to everything near it.  Only real beef is how ugly Nottam Portant's hair looks, but you're not playing the game to look at his hair - or if you are, you're not going to get very far.

solid 8/10 and becomes 11/10 when you blast dethklok as you play the game

reviewText:
Well... Hatred is here, and it sucks.

Okay, first of all, I don't have a particular problem with the game's theme itself. Unfortunately, our society isn't perfect and yes, there are tragic occurrences when some bolk goes mad and kills a lot of people out of God knows what. It happens. And as such, a game in fact has every right to touch such a sad subject. It's not even a new thing, just check on Postal for instance!

But man, Destructive Creations screwed up everything they could do right in this case. The engine itself was a bad idea, UE4 is poorly optimized and unnecessary for a top-down-view shooter, Unity would have been a far better choice. The game is sluggish, runs horribly on the same PC that makes GTA V fly, and ugly as hell too. So there's that.

In the terms of gameplay, it shows nothing new, and gets boring after a few minutes. Is it cool to kill people without a reason? Well maybe it could be, but isn't, thanks for the horrible AI that makes them feel like mindless idiots wandering like zombies. It's just bad.

Just like the shooting mechanic: aiming is difficult, there is no cover system, the enemy is always overpowered, and it's just simply not fun to shoot. Which is sad because in such a game, using guns might be a selling point.

And the game ends in 4 hours, giving us absolutely no reason to play it again. Sorry DC, this isn't the crusade we wish to see.

reviewText:
Its not that Hatred is a bad game its just not a great game either.  You play as a man who's purpose is just to kill everything, the game plays like any other top-down twin stick shooter with you using a wide array of weapons to kill everything on screen.  As i said the games not bad but not great either, there are plenty of other games like this which are better and contain co-op play.

I enjoy using the weapons in the game and I do like the art style the game has chosen where the game is all in black or white except for blood and police lights.  There is never a dull moment in this game as your always firing your gun at something and this game has some awesome destruction physics in which buildings can be shot up or blown up which is great for making a getaway when trapped.

However there is a lot of things i did not like such as the horrible dialog and one liners your character makes, it makes 80s action movie quotes seem like poetry by comparison, the camera control is probelly the biggest enemy of all as you try to shoot something in front but instead the camera is zoomed at the bottom limiting your view and the combat does not feel very precise.  lastly the Frame rate is pretty bad for a top down game with me only getting about 40 FPS with a 980.

Once again not a bad game especilly for the devolpers first game so far but i can not reccommend this game as being worthy of the price or your time when there are better games than this.  Its nothing more than a mediocre game that trys to be edgy and falls a little flat.

...and so here it is, Hatred. Twin stick shooter where you just shoot civilians. Does it live up to it's hype? Not quite, but that doesn't mean it's bad either.

It's somewhere in between. Certainly a good game when you want to relieve some stress, shoot some people up and then close it, only to come back to it the next day for same short session. Don't expect miracles, don't expect deep story or even name of character, you just shoot people.

You know what? It's not a bad thing at all. Destruction mechanics, shooting mechanics are cool and kinda realistic. It's fun to shoot civilians, but sadly executions get tad repetive. Game is also kinda hard.

I like the game's aesthethic. It's black and white, with some colour from sirens of police cars and few other smaller things. Optimisation is a bit bad but devs will resolve it, I'm sure of it, more after the service they were doing to fans.

It's alright. Strong 7/10, but is it worth the full price asking now? Well for value I got from here so far, I'd say yeah. There are much worse games (Grass simulator) that offer nothing at all, yet they cost $10, and this here? Offers heavy atmostphere, heavy soundtrack that further adds to how intense this game is, destruction physics that allow you to literally destroy entire houses and fun shooting mechanics.

Get it now or wait for price drop. Whatever floats your boat. It's not THAT brutal, it's not bad, it's not excellent, it's alright, and that's more than enough for me to like it.
